PREFACE 
    The Laramie, Wyoming Municipal Code, originally published by Book Publishing Company in 1982, has been kept current by regular supplementation by Matthew Bender & Company, Inc., its successor in interest. 
    During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and indexed by the editorial staff of Book Publishing Company under the direction of Thomas S. Smith, city attorney. 
    This 2011 republication includes all amendatory legislation through Ordinance No. 1819, adopted Dec. 21, 2010, and was accomplished under the supervision of Eric Grant, Supplement Department Vice President, and Katrina Hansen, Editor. 
    The code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number designates, in sequence, the numbers of the Title, chapter, and section. Thus, Section 2.12.040 is Section .040, located in Chapter 2.12 of Title 2. In most instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions. Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion. 
    In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table, following the text of the code, listing by number all ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification. Legislation can be tracked using the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
    This republication brings the code up to date through Ordinance No. 1758 , passed on December 18, 2018. 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
800-262-2633 
HOW TO USE YOUR CODE 
    This code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials, city employees and private citizens. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code. 
Numbering System. 
    The numbering system is the backbone of a Code of Ordinances; Municipal Code Corporation uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this Code. It is based on three tiers, beginning with title, then chapter, and ending with section. Each part is represented in the code section number. For example, Section 2.04.010 is Section .010, in Chapter 2.04 of Title 2. 
Title. 
    A title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled. This code contains about 15 to 20 titles. For example, the first title is Title 1, General Provisions, which may contain ordinances about the general penalty, code adoption and definitions. The titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference. Some titles are Reserved for later use. 
Chapter. 
    Chapters deal with more specific subjects, and are often derived from one ordinance. All of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title. The chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material. For example, Chapter 2.06, City Manager, can be added between 2.04, City Council, and Chapter 2.08, City Attorney. 
Section. 
    Each section of the code contains substantive ordinance material. The sections are numbered by "tens" to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering. 
Tables of Contents. 
    There are many tables of contents in this code to assist in locating specific information. At the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title, chapter and divisions, with specific page locations. In addition, each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters, divisions and sections, respectively. 
Ordinance History Note. 
    At the end of each code section, you will find an "ordinance history note," which lists the underlying ordinances for that section. The ordinances are listed by number, section (if applicable) and year. (Example: (Ord. 272 § 1, 1992).) 
    Ordinance history notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end. These history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index. 
Statutory References. 
    The statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality. As the statutes are revised, these references will be updated. 
Cross-Reference Table. 
    When a code is based on an earlier codification, the cross-reference table will help users find older or "prior" code references in the new code. The cross-reference table is located near the end of the code, under the tabbed divider "Tables." This table lists the prior code section in the column labeled "Prior Code Section" and the new code section in the column labeled "Herein." 
    This table is no longer updated. 
Ordinance List and Disposition Table. 
    To find a specific ordinance in the code, turn to the section called "Tables" for the Ordinance List and Disposition Table. This very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code. The table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance. If the ordinance is codified, the chapter (or chapters) will be indicated. (Example: (2.04, 6.12, 9.04).) If the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified, such as budgets, taxes, annexations or rezones, the disposition will be "(Special)." If the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code, usually at the direction of the municipality, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." Other dispositions sometimes used are "(Tabled)," "(Pending)," "(Number Not Used)" or "(Missing)." 
    This table has been replaced with the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 
    A Code Comparative Table and Disposition List has been added for use in tracking legislative history. Located in the back of this volume, this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification. The Code Comparative Table and Disposition List specifies the ordinance number, adoption date, description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance. By use of the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List, the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
Index. 
    If you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code, start with the index. This is an alphabetical multi-tier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference, and cross-references where necessary. Look for the main heading of the subject you need, then the appropriate subheadings: 
BUSINESS LICENSE 
See also BUSINESS TAX 
Fee 5.04.030 
Required when 5.04.010 
    The index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended. 
Instruction Sheet. 
    Each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an Instruction Sheet. The Instruction Sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement. It will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted. Following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current. Removed pages should be kept for future reference. 
Page Numbering System. 
    The page numbering system used in this code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a title of the code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the title. When new pages are inserted with amendments, the pages will follow a "Point Numbering System". (Example: 32, 32.1, 32.2, 32.2.1, 32.2.2., 33). Backs of pages that are blank (in codes that are printed double-sided) will be left unnumbered but the number will be "reserved" for later use. 
Electronic Submission. 
    In the interests of accuracy and speed, we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible. We can accept most any file format, including Word, WordPerfect or text files. If you have a choice, we prefer Word, any version. You can send files to us as an e-mail attachment, by FTP, on a diskette or CD-ROM. Electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is error-free. Our e-mail address is: ords@municode.com. 
For hard copy, send two copies of all ordinances passed to: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
P.O. Box 2235 
Tallahassee, FL 32316 
Customer Service. 
    If you have any questions about this code or our services, please contact Municipal Code Corporation at 1-800-262-2633 or: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
  
    The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omitted." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 1.01 - CODE ADOPTION 
Sections: 

1.01.010 - Adoption. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of W.S. 15-1-103 (xxxviii), there is hereby adopted the "Laramie Municipal Code." 
(Ord. 704 § 1, 1982) 
1.01.020 - Title-Citation-Reference. 
    This code shall be known as the "Laramie Municipal Code" and it shall be sufficient to refer to said code as the "Laramie Municipal Code" in any prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding at law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to, amending, correcting or repealing all or any part or portion thereof as an addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the "Laramie Municipal Code." Further reference may be had to the titles, chapters, sections and subsections of the "Laramie Municipal Code" and such references shall apply to that numbered title, chapter, section or subsection as it appears in the code. 
(Ord. 704 § 2, 1982) 
1.01.030 - Codification authority. 
    This code consists of all the regulatory and penal ordinances and certain of the administrative ordinances of the city of Laramie, Wyoming, codified pursuant to the provisions of W.S. 15-1-103(xxxviii). 
(Ord. 704 § 3, 1982) 
1.01.040 - Ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code. 
    The last ordinances included in the initial code is Enrolled Ordinance No. 660, passed March 3, 1981, and Ordinance No. 670, passed May 19, 1981. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to Ordinance No. 660 and Ordinance No. 670, but prior to adoption of this code, are hereby adopted and made a part of this code: 
    Ordinance No. 661, relative to procedures for conditional zoning; 
    Ordinance No. 662, establishing a planned unit development zoning classification; 
    Ordinance No. 663, amending the code of the city of Laramie, Wyoming, relating to gambling; 
    Ordinance No. 664, providing for the payment of a plant investment fee as a condition to connecting to the water and sewer system of the city; 
    Ordinance No. 665, adding small animal veterinary clinics to the list of uses permitted in the B2 zone; 
    Ordinance No. 666, relating to the manner in which motor vehicles must park in metered areas; 
    Ordinance No. 667, amending the sewer service rate schedule and establishing new procedure for determining equitable service charges to be levied on all users which discharge wastewater to the wastewater system operated by the city of Laramie; 
    Ordinance No. 668, amending Enrolled Ordinance No. 585 relating to flood zones of the city of Laramie by prohibiting certain sewerage connections; 
    Ordinance No. 672, adopting the 1978 recommendations of the U.S. Public Health Service; 
    Ordinance No. 673, establishing a street name designation committee, and establishing procedures for designation or redesignation of street names; 
    Ordinance No. 675, adopting a major street plan; providing procedures for amendment; for preservation of areas within designated streets; and acquisition of such areas by eminent domain proceedings, and providing penalties for violation; 
    Ordinance No. 679, repealing Chapter 24A of the Code of the City of Laramie relating to noise; 
    Ordinance No. 680, prohibiting parking at the corner of certain designated intersections and amending Sections 6.1(4) and 9.2 of Appendix A and Sections 23-30.1 of the code relating to parking; 
    Ordinance No. 681, changing the city employee responsible for handling city warrants from the city clerk to the city treasurer and by changing the word "stub" to the word "copy"; 
    Ordinance No. 682, enacting a noise control policy for the city of Laramie; 
    Ordinance No. 683, repealing Sections 26-22 to 26-25 of the code relating to the Ivinson Hospital Quiet Zone; 
    Ordinance No. 684, concerning the disposition of unclaimed property by the chief of police; 
    Ordinance No. 685, establishing a presumption that the registered owner of a motor vehicle was its operator at the time of a parking offense; 
    Ordinance No. 687, amending and re-enacting Section 1 of Enrolled Ordinance No. 614 of the Code of the City of Laramie relative to secondhand dealers; 
    Ordinance No. 697, amending Enrolled Ordinance No. 667 of the City of Laramie sewer service rate schedule by adding an increase in charge to users discharging toxic pollutants and by adjusting volume of flow definitions; 
    Ordinance No. 698, adding to those uses permitted in a B1 zoning district to include retail sign shops; 
    Ordinance No. 699, concerning service charges and rules for the city cemetery: 
    Ordinance No. 700, establishing the offense of trespass. 
(Ord. 704 § 4, 1982) 
1.01.050 - Reference applies to all amendments. 
    Whenever a reference is made to this code as the "Laramie Municipal Code" or to any portion thereof, or to any ordinance of the City of Laramie, Wyoming, the reference shall apply to all amendments, corrections and additions heretofore, now or hereafter made. 
(Ord. 704 § 5, 1982) 
1.01.060 - Title, chapter and section headings. 
    Title, chapter and section headings contained in this code shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any title, chapter or section of this code. 
(Ord. 704 § 6, 1982) 
1.01.090 - Effective date. 
    The provisions of this code shall be in force on and after July 1, 1982. 
(Ord. 704 § 9, 1982) 
1.01.100 - Constitutionality. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this code. The council declares that it would have passed this code, and each section, subsection, sentence, clause and phrase thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases had been declared invalid or unconstitutional, and if for any reason this code should be declared invalid or unconstitutional, then the original ordinance or ordinances shall be in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 704 § 10, 1982) 
Chapter 1.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

1.04.010 - Short title. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as "The code of the city of Laramie, Wyoming," and may be so cited. The code may also be cited as the "Laramie city code." 
(Ord. 622 § 1, 1980) 
1.04.020 - Definitions 
    In the construction of this code and of all ordinances of the city, the following definitions as rules of construction shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
1.  Bond: when a bond is required, it shall be provided by a qualified third party surety authorized to do business in Wyoming, unless the city council otherwise requires. 
2.  "City" means the city of Laramie, in the country of Albany, in the state of Wyoming. 
3.  "City council" or "council" means the city council of the city of Laramie, Wyoming. "Council member" means a qualified member of the council, elected or appointed thereto on accordance with all applicable provisions of law. 
4.  Computation of time: the time within which ac act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; and if the day; is a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
5.  "Country" means the country of Albany, in the state of Wyoming. 
6.  Gender: words importing the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter. 
7.  "In the city" means and includes any territory within the corporate limits of the city of Laramie, Wyoming, and the police jurisdiction thereof, and any other territory over which regulatory power has been conferred by a general or special act. 
8.  Joint authority: all words giving a joint authority to three of more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
9.  "Month" means a calendar month. 
10.  Number: words used in the singular include the plural and words used in the plural include the singular. 
11.  "Oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" are equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
12.  "Owner," applied to a building or land, includes not only the owner of the whole, but any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common or joint tenant of the whole or a part of such building or land, and includes any agent of such owner, and where such owner is a body corporate, it includes the managing agent or officer within the city. 
13.  "Person" includes a firm, partnership, association of persons, corporation, organization or any other group acting as a unit, as well as an individual. 
14.  "Personal property" includes every species of property, except real property. 
15.  "Preceding" and "following" means next before and next after, respectively. 
16.  "Municipal judge" means the duly appointed judge of the municipal court or duly appointed alternate as that term is used in W.S. 5-6-102, and any amendments thereto. 
17.  "Property" includes real, personal and mixed property. 
18.  "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
19.  "Shall" is mandatory and "may" is permissive. 
20.  "Sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
21.  "Signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write, when his name is written near such mark and is witnessed by a person who writes his own name as a witness. 
22.  "State" means the state of Wyoming. 
23.  "Street" means and includes public streets, avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto and all other public thoroughfares in the city. 
24.  "Tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, mean any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
25.  Time: words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
26.  "Writing" and "written" include typewriting, printing on paper and any other mode of representing words and letters. 
27.  "Year" means a calendar year. 
(Ord. 622 § 2, 1980; Ord. 711 § 1, 1982; Ord. 863 § 1, 1986; Ord. 1286 §§ 1-4, 1999) 
1.04.030 - Provisions considered continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this code, so far as they are the same as those of the code and ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Ord. 622 § 3, 1980) 
1.04.040 - Catchlines. 
    The catchlines of the sections of this code, printed in boldface type, are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections, and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of any section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any section, including its catchline, is amended or re-enacted. 
(Ord. 622 § 4, 1980) 
Chapter 1.08 - CITY SEAL 
Sections: 

1.08.010 - Generally. 
    A seal, the impression of which shall be as follows: in the center, a locomotive and train of cars crossing a culvert; in the background, a range of mountains and setting sun; around the outer edge, the words, "Seal of the City of Laramie, Wyoming," is adopted and declared to be the seal of the city. 
(Prior code § 1-8) 
Chapter 1.12 - ORDINANCES 
Sections: 

1.12.010 - Public reading-Generally. 
    Every ordinance, other than emergency ordinances, shall be publicly read on three different days. Public reading may be by title only. At least ten days shall elapse between the introduction and the final passage of every ordinance, except emergency ordinances. 
(Prior code § 2-28 (part); Ord. 594 § 1 (part), 1979) 
1.12.020 - Public reading-Exception. 
    Every ordinance, except emergency ordinances, shall have public readings on three different days, unless three-fourths of the governing body votes to suspend the rule. At least ten days shall elapse between the introduction and final passage of every ordinance, except emergency ordinances. No franchise may be granted by emergency ordinance. 
(Prior code § 2-27 (part); Ord. 623 § 1(c), 1980) 
1.12.040 - Passage-Emergency ordinances. 
    Passage of an ordinance shall require the affirmative vote of the majority of the qualified members of the governing body. The passage of an emergency ordinance requires the affirmative vote of three-fourths of the qualified members of the city council. 
(Prior code § 2-30; Ord. 595 § 1, 1979; Ord. 838 § 2, 1985) 
1.12.050 - Signing and recording. 
    Every ordinance or resolution shall be signed by the mayor or in the absence of the mayor, the vice-mayor or president pro tem, and attested by the city clerk, and every ordinance shall be published at least once in the official paper within ten days after its passage. Every ordinance after its enactment shall be recorded in a book kept for that purpose, which record shall be attested by the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 2-31; Ord. 738 § 1, 1983; Ord. 838 § 3, 1985) 
1.12.060 - Amendments-Generally. 
    Amendments and repeals of ordinances or sections thereof shall be by ordinance. An amending ordinance shall set forth the entire ordinance or section as amended. 
(Prior code § 2-32) 
1.12.070 - Amendments-Procedure. 
    Amendments to a proposed ordinance may be made at any time before the proposed ordinance is put upon its final passage, and if amendments are adopted, the proposed ordinance shall be put upon its final passage as amended. It shall, however, not be necessary to show on the records of the city clerk that amendments have been made, if the amendments are made by insertions in the proposed ordinance at the time such amendments are adopted. The ordinance introduced, as corrected and amended, shall constitute the ordinance to be submitted to the mayor for approval, unless otherwise ordered. 
(Prior code § 2-28 (part); Ord. 594 § 1 (part), 1979) 
1.12.080 - Emergency ordinances. 
    For an emergency ordinance, the requirements of this chapter may be suspended by the affirmative vote of three-fourths of the elected and qualified members of the city council. An emergency ordinance is one operating for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health or safety in which the emergency is defined and declared in a preamble thereto, separately voted on and that receives the affirmative vote of all council members present at the meeting; provided, that no grant of a franchise shall be made by an emergency ordinance. An emergency ordinance may be enacted without previous filing. 
(Prior code § 2-28 (part); Ord. 594 § 1 (part), 1979) 
1.12.090 - Legislation to be by ordinance. 
    All municipal legislation shall be by ordinance, unless provided otherwise by law, except that licenses may be granted by resolution. 
(Prior code § 2-27 (part); Ord. 623 § 1(a), 1980) 
1.12.100 - Style. 
    All ordinances shall be in writing and passed pursuant to rules and regulations adopted by the governing body. No ordinance, except one making appropriations, may contain more than one subject, which shall be expressed clearly in the title. Ordinances making appropriations shall be limited to those respective subjects. The style of all ordinances shall be: "Be it ordained by the governing body of the City of Laramie." 
(Prior code § 2-27 (part); Ord. 623 § 1(b), 1980) 
Chapter 1.16 - LICENSES 
Sections: 

1.16.010 - Generally. 
    All licenses which may be issued under this code or other ordinances of this city shall be subject to the provisions of this code and other ordinances and regulations which may be in force at the time of the issuing thereof or which may be subsequently established by the city council. 
(Prior code § 21-1) 
1.16.020 - Applications-Contents. 
    Except as otherwise expressly specified, any person desiring to obtain a license under the provisions of this code shall make application to the city manager for the license. The application shall be in writing, and shall contain a description of the premises where the business or thing to be licensed is located (where the business is not located in a permanent place, the application shall describe the character of the business or occupation), the period of time for which the license is to run and the kind of license desired. The application shall be signed by the applicant. 
(Prior code § 21-2) 
1.16.030 - Applications-Heard by city manager. 
    In all cases where it is not otherwise expressly provided, the city manager or designee shall hear applications for, and approve or disapprove the issuing of licensing upon the terms specified by this code. 
(Prior code § 21-3; Ord. 1288 § 1, 1999) 
1.16.040 - Maximum term. 
    No license under this code shall be granted at any one time for a longer period than one year, except for licenses for public or private utilities using or crossing public right-of-way which may be granted for a reasonable term in the discretion of the city council. 
(Prior code § 21-4; Ord. 1288 § 2, 1999) 
1.16.050 - Transferability. 
    Unless otherwise expressly authorized, no license granted under this code or other city ordinance shall be assignable or transferable without permission of the issuing authority, nor shall any such license authorize any person to do business or act under it other than the person named therein or the person to whom such license is transferred. All annual licenses may be transferred by permission of the issuing authority. All licenses issued are personal privileges and may not be transferred, unless otherwise expressly provided. 
(Prior code § 21-5) 
1.16.060 - Compliance with chapter required. 
    No person shall be deemed to be licensed in any case until the issuing of a license in due form, as provided in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 21-6) 
1.16.070 - Revocation. 
    If any person licensed under this code or other ordinances of the city violates any of the provisions thereof, he shall be liable to be proceeded against for any fine or penalty imposed thereby, and in addition to such fine or penalty, his license shall be subject to revocation in the discretion of the issuing authority, or as otherwise specifically provided in this code. 
(Prior code § 21-7) 
Chapter 1.20 - ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE 
Sections: 

1.20.010 - Adoption. 
    In accordance with the provisions of W.S. 9-276.19 through 9-276.33, these rules of practice and procedure are adopted. 
(Prior code § 2-47) 
1.20.020 - Scope. 
    These rules of practice and procedure are applicable only in contested cases, as defined in W.S. 9-276.19, before the city council, the fire department civil service commission, the police department civil service commission, the zoning board of adjustment and the building code board of appeals. 
(Prior code § 2-48) 
1.20.030 - Petitions-Initiation. 
    All contested cases to which these rules of practice and procedure apply shall be initiated either by the council, commission or board or by a contestee, upon a written verified petition wherein shall be alleged the acts or omissions from which the contestee is aggrieved or adversely affected. The petition shall be filed within ten days of the act or omission from which the petitioner is aggrieved or adversely affected. 
(Prior code § 2-49) 
1.20.040 - Petitions-Contents. 
    The verified petition shall be filed with the city clerk and shall set forth: 
A.  The name of the agency to which the petition is directed; 
B.  The name and address of each contestee and his attorney, if any; 
C.  The legal description and a plat plan of real property involved in the contest, if any; 
D.  A statement in ordinary and concise language, of the facts upon which the petition is based including reference to statutory law, ordinances, rules, regulations and orders, and including any instruments or documents, involved in the allegations therein contained; 
E.  A concise request or prayer for the specific relief desired. 
(Prior code § 2-50) 
1.20.050 - Petitions-Service. 
    The petitioner shall cause to be served upon all agencies and persons named in the petition a full, true and correct copy thereof. Service shall be made personally or by registered or certified mail with return receipt thereof in accordance with the provisions of Rule 4 of the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure; provided, however, that personal service made within the city may be made by a member of the police department. In the case of the agency, service shall be made upon the mayor of the city council or the chairman of the board or commission involved. Proof of service shall be made in accordance with the provisions of such Rule 4. 
(Prior code § 2-51) 
1.20.060 - Petitions-Answer. 
    The agencies or persons against whom the petition has been filed shall be allowed twenty days from and after the date of service of the petition within which to file with the city clerk his, her or its answer or other appearance. A copy of such answer or other appearance shall be served upon the petitioner in accordance with the provisions of Rule 5 of the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure. 
(Prior code § 2-52) 
1.20.070 - Petitions-Filing. 
    When proceedings are instituted by the filing of a petition as provided in this chapter, the city clerk shall assign it a number and enter it with the date of its filing on a separate page of a docket provided for that purpose. The city clerk shall keep separate dockets for the city council, the fire department civil service commission, the police department civil service commission, the zoning board of adjustment and the building code board of appeals and shall establish a separate file for each docketed case, in which shall be placed all pleadings, documents, papers, transcripts, evidence and exhibits pertaining thereto, and all such items shall have noted thereon, the docket number assigned, and the date of filing. There shall be a filing fee in the amount of ten dollars which shall be paid to the city clerk at the time of filing of the verified petition. 
(Prior code § 2-53) 
1.20.080 - Presentation of proceedings after failing to respond. 
    In the event of failure of either the council, commission or board as the case may be, or any contestee to answer or otherwise appear within the time allowed by these rules; and provided, that Section 1.20.050 has been complied with, such agency or contestee so failing to answer or otherwise appear, shall not be allowed to answer or otherwise appear thereafter and after written notice to the petitioner, the proceedings will be brought before the agency to which it was presented for consideration and appropriate action. 
(Prior code § 2-53.1) 
1.20.090 - Proceedings-Settlements without hearings. 
    Any proceedings initiated as provided in this chapter may be concluded by stipulation, agreed settlement, consent order or default of the parties or motion and order of dismissal if such disposition is approved by the agency before which it was initiated. If proceedings are so disposed, of an appropriate order, they shall be entered and included in the case record. 
(Prior code § 2-53.2) 
1.20.100 - Proceedings-Motions heard after notice. 
    The agency before which the proceedings were initiated may, after ten days' notice given in accordance with Section 1.20.130, hear any motion filed in connection with any proceedings initiated pursuant to these rules. 
(Prior code § 2-53.3) 
1.20.110 - Proceedings-Depositions and discovery. 
    Any part to proceedings initiated pursuant to these rules may take depositions and discovery in accordance with W.S. 9-276.25(g)(1), (h). 
(Prior code § 2-53.4) 
1.20.120 - Proceedings-Prehearing conference. 
    Prior to the day of hearing, the agency before which the proceedings were initiated may direct the parties to the proceedings or their attorneys to appear before the agency for a pre-hearing conference. 
(Prior code § 2-53.5) 
1.20.130 - Proceedings-Hearing-Notice. 
    After the issues of the case have been joined the agency before which the proceedings were initiated shall set a date, time and place for hearing. The agency shall give notice of hearing to all parties of the proceedings in accordance with the provisions of W.S. 9-276.25. Such notice shall be given personally or by certified or. registered mail with return receipt thereof not less than fifteen days prior to the date of hearing. If notice of hearing is given by mail the computation of time shall begin to run on the date the notice is deposited in the United States mail. All issues and matters involved in the proceedings shall be presented on behalf of the council, commission or board, as the case may be, by an officer or agent of such council, commission or board as designated by it. Any contestee may be represented personally or by counsel subject to the provisions of Section 2-53.11. 
(Prior code § 2-53.6) 
1.20.140 - Proceedings-Subpoenas. 
    The presiding officer of the agency before which proceedings are initiated pursuant to these rules shall, upon written request of any party to the proceedings, issue subpoenas for appearance or to produce books, papers or other documents or subpoenas duces tecum in accordance with the provisions of W.S. 9-276.25(c), (d), (e), (f). 
(Prior code § 2-53.7) 
1.20.150 - Proceedings-Hearing-Procedure. 
    As nearly as may be, hearings shall be conducted in accordance with the following order of procedure: 
A.  The presiding officer of the agency before which the hearing is being conducted shall announce that the hearing is convened upon the call of the docket number and title of the matter to be heard and shall direct the reading into the record of the formal notice of hearing given by the agency, and shall note for the record all subpoenas issued and all appearances of record including contestees and their counsels of record. 
B.  The petitioner or his or its agent or attorney shall be allowed to make an opening statement to briefly explain his position to the agency and to outline the evidence he proposes to offer. 
C.  The petitioner or his or its agent or attorney shall thereupon proceed to present his evidence. Witnesses may be cross-examined by the other parties and may be examined by members of the agency. All exhibits offered by and on behalf of the petitioner shall be marked by letters of the alphabet beginning with "A." 
D.  The other party or parties shall, in the order of answers or appearances made, be heard in the same manner as the petitioner. 
1.  They shall be allowed to make an opening statement in the same manner and for the same purpose as the petitioner. 
2.  Their evidence, witnesses and exhibits shall be presented and heard in the same manner as allowed the petitioner and their exhibits shall be marked by numbers beginning with "1." 
E.  The agency may, in its discretion, allow evidence to be offered out of order. 
F.  At the conclusion of the presentation of the other party's evidence, the petitioner may present rebuttal evidence. 
G.  At the conclusion of the petitioner's rebuttal evidence, or if there is no rebuttal evidence, at the conclusion of other party's evidence, the chairman of the agency shall declare the evidence closed. 
H.  1.  Closing statements will be made in the following sequence: 
a.  Petitioner; 
b.  Other party or parties; 
c.  Petitioner in rebuttal; 
2.  The time for oral argument or closing statement may be limited by the agency. 
I.  After all the proceedings have been concluded, the agency shall declare the hearing closed. Any party may tender briefs of law to the agency and the agency may call for such briefs as they may deem advisable or grant a party a reasonable time within which to prepare and submit briefs to aid the agency in arriving at a decision. The agency shall take the case under advisement and shall declare that its decision will be announced within a reasonable time following consideration of all the matters presented at the hearing. 
(Prior code § 2-53.8) 
1.20.160 - Proceedings-Hearing-Sworn witnesses. 
    All persons testifying at any hearing pursuant to these rules shall stand and be administered the following oath by either the presiding officer or secretary of the agency: 
    Do you swear (or affirm) to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth in this hearing now before the (name of agency)? 
(Prior code § 2-53.9) 
1.20.170 - Proceedings-Hearing-Applicability of state law. 
    The following rules of practice and procedure contained in the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure insofar as the same may be applicable and not inconsistent with the laws of the state in matters before an agency and applicable to the rules, orders and regulations promulgated by an agency under such laws, shall apply: 4 (c) (d) (m) (1) (2) (i, ii, iii, v) (n); 5; 6; 10; 11; 17(a); 20; 26; 28 through 37 (except Rule 37(b) (1) and 37(b) (2) (iv) therefrom; 45; 72.1. 
(Prior code § 2-53.10) 
1.20.180 - Proceedings-Hearing-Attorneys. 
    The filing of an answer or other appearance by an attorney constitutes his appearance for the party for whom the pleading is filed. The agency before which the proceedings are initiated shall be notified in writing of an attorney's withdrawal from any hearing. Any person appearing before an agency at a hearing in a representative capacity shall be precluded from examining or cross-examining any witness unless such person is an attorney licensed to practice law in the state or a nonresident attorney associated with a state attorney qualified to practice law in the state. This rule shall not be construed to prohibit any person from representing himself in any hearing before an agency. 
(Prior code § 2-53.11) 
1.20.190 - Proceedings-Hearing-Recordation. 
    When oral testimony of witnesses is taken in contested cases before an agency, the proceedings, including all testimony, shall be reported verbatim by a competent reporter. The compensation of such reporter shall be paid by the unsuccessful party or as otherwise ordered by the agency. If a transcript of testimony is required in the subsequent agency deliberations, the cost thereof shall be furnished to the agency by the unsuccessful party. 
(Prior code 2-53.12) 
1.20.200 - Proceedings-Hearing-Decision. 
    The agency before which the hearing is conducted shall, following the full and complete hearing, make and enter a written decision and order in all contested cases, in accordance with the provisions of W.S. 9-276.28. Such decisions and orders shall be filed with the agency and will, without further action, become the decision and order as a result of the hearing. Forthwith upon entry and filing, the agency shall send a copy by prepaid mail to each party or his attorney of record. 
(Prior code § 2-53.13) 
1.20.210 - Proceedings-Decision-Rate making and licensing. 
    In all contested cases conducted in accordance with these rules of practice and procedure the subject of which is rate making, price fixing or licensing, the decision of the agency before which the proceedings are initiated shall be final and shall not be subject to review or rehearing by such agency. Subsequent petitions requesting the same or similar relief shall not be accepted by the city clerk or considered by an agency subject to these rules for a period of twelve months following the entry of the decision of the agency before which the original proceedings were initiated. 
(Prior code § 2-53.14) 
1.20.220 - Proceedings-Appeal of decision. 
    Appeals to the district court from decisions of an agency are governed by W.S. 9-276.32 and Rule 72.1 of the Rules of Civil Procedure promulgated by the Supreme Court of the state. 
(Prior code § 2-53.15) 
1.20.230 - Proceedings-Appeal of decision-Filing transcript. 
    In case of an appeal to the district court, the party appealing shall secure and file a transcript of the testimony and all other evidence offered at the hearing which transcript must be verified by the oath of the reporter who took the testimony as a true and correct transcript of the testimony and other evidence in the case. The compensation of the reporter for making the transcript of the testimony and all other costs involved in such appeal shall be borne by the party prosecuting such appeal. 
(Prior code § 2-53.16) 
1.20.240 - Proceedings-Applicability of Administrative Procedure Act. 
In all proceedings before an agency pursuant to these rules, the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act (W.S. 276. 19 through 9-276.3 3) shall apply. If a conflict arises between such Act and these rules, the Act shall supersede these rules. 
(Prior code § 2-53.17) 
1.20.250 - Proceedings-Applicability of Administrative Procedure Act-Amendments. 
    Amendments to these rules shall be promulgated and become effective as provided in W.S. 9-276.21 and 9-276.22. 
(Prior code § 2-53.18) 
Chapter 1.24 - MUNICIPAL COURT 
Sections: 

1.24.010 - Created-Jurisdiction. 
    The municipal court of this city is created, which shall be presided over by a municipal judge. The municipal court and the municipal judge presiding therein shall have exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine all cases arising under this code and other ordinances of this city for a violation thereof. No change of venue shall be granted in any case. 
(Ord. 983 § 1,1989: prior code § 24-1) 
1.24.020 - Bail bond-Amount. 
    The amount in a bond for admission to bail shall in no case exceed seven hundred fifty dollars. If the principal in such bond fails to appear according to the condition of the bond or appearing, departs the court without leave, 
the municipal judge shall note the fact upon the bond and issue a summons in behalf of the city against the parties liable thereon. Upon trial of such cause, the same defense shall be allowed as under the general laws of the state in like cases before justices of the peace. 
(Prior code § 24-7; Ord. 713 § 1, 1982; Ord. 983 § 2, 1989) 
1.24.030 - Bail bond-Failure to post. 
    A party in custody who cannot be tried on account of the absence of witnesses or other cause and who cannot give bail for his appearance may be confined in the city jail not exceeding three days, and in such case the municipal judge shall deliver to the proper office a commitment, stating the cause of detention. 
(Prior code § 24-8; Ord. 983 § 3, 1989) 
1.24.040 - Police chief and municipal judge-Determination of duties. 
    The municipal judge and the chief of police, in all matters pertaining to the duties of their respective offices in judicial proceedings and concerning which there is no specific provision by the city charter or by this code or other ordinances of this city, shall be governed by the laws of this state regulating the practices and proceedings in cases before justices of the peace and constables, so far as the same may be applicable. 
(Prior code § 24-10; Ord. 983 § 4, 1989) 
1.24.050 - Court costs. 
A.  The municipal court judge shall impose court costs upon a guilty plea or finding of violations of municipal code (W.S. 5-6-108, W.S. 5-6-204): 
1.  Ten dollars court costs. 
2.  Court automation costs and the portion retained by the city solely for the purpose of defraying costs and expenses related to establishing and maintaining an electronic citation system shall be set by resolution. The balance of the fee will be submitted to the state to comply with the requirements of the judicial systems automation account. 
B.  No costs shall be imposed on defendants: 
1.  Acquitted or found not guilty after a trial of the merits. 
2.  Parking violations of the Laramie Municipal Code. 
(Prior code § 24-12; Ord. 983 § 5, 1989; Ord. No. 1686 , § 1, 8-18-2015; Ord. No. 1737 , § 1, 8-1-2017) 
1.24.060 - Confinement for failure to pay judgment. 
    Upon the rendition, in municipal court, of judgment against any defendant for the violation of this code or any other ordinance of this city, the municipal judge shall make an order and enter the same upon his docket, that if the defendant shall neglect or refuse to satisfy such judgment and costs of the suit, he shall be confined in the city jail one day for each twenty-five dollars of such judgment and costs. 
(Prior code § 24-12; Ord. 712 § 1, 1982; Ord. 983 § 6, 1989) 
1.24.070 - Accuser liable for court costs if charges deemed malicious. 
    In all prosecutions in the municipal court, for fine or penalty, when the defendant is acquitted, -the informer or prosecutor may, in the discretion of the municipal judge, be adjudged to pay the costs, if it appears to the satisfaction of the municipal judge that the prosecution was instituted vexatiously, maliciously or without reasonable cause, and the judgment shall be so rendered and executions shall issue therefor. 
(Prior code § 24-14; Ord. 983 § 7, 1989) 
1.24.080 - Reserved. 
1.24.090 - Reserved. 
1.24.100 - Notices to appear. 
A.  Any police officer or other person authorized by the chief of police may issue a notice of violation to any person who has violated any ordinance of this city concerning: 
1.  Vehicle parking, by affixing to or depositing in an automobile or other vehicle found to be parked in violation of a municipal ordinance a notice of violation indicating thereon the location of the place where the violation occurred, the date upon which the violation occurred, the license number of the vehicle, and notice of time and date the owner of the vehicle is required to appear in municipal court to answer to the charge of violation. A notice to appear may be issued for abandoned vehicles, for vehicles parked in violation of any ordinance pertaining to snow emergency routes, any ordinance allowing the removal of vehicles for street cleaning and snow removal, for mobile homes unlawfully parked upon streets, overtime parking, illegal parking and any other ordinance pertaining to vehicle parking or removal of illegally parked vehicles; 
    The owner of any vehicle who fails to appear in court at the time fixed in the notice shall be formally charged by complaint and warrant with violation of the applicable municipal ordinance and shall be brought before the court to be dealt with in accordance with law; 
2.  Any provision of Title 6 of this code entitled "Animals;" 
3.  Any ordinance pertaining to the distribution of handbills and flyers; 
4.  Any ordinance concerning spilled or drained motor oil or other hydrocarbons; 
5.  Any ordinance for which a citation could be issued by a peace officer after investigation of a traffic accident except ordinance which are not bondable or where a custodial arrest is involved; 
6.  Any ordinance pertaining to snow removal, sidewalk obstructions or placing snow in the street. 
    Any notice of violation shall contain the name of the violator if known, the location of the place where the violation occurred, the date upon which the violation occurred, the license number of the vehicle if a vehicle is involved and notice of time and date the owner of the vehicle or person subject to the notice is required to appear in municipal court to answer to the charge of violation. 
B.  1.  If any person receiving any notice of violation, except for a notice for animal cruelty pursuant to Section 6.20.010 or animal neglect pursuant to Section 6.20.013, does not desire to appear before the court to answer the charge, he may pay the maximum penalty in cash. Where the ordinance does not specify a mandatory penalty, the person may pay in cash the amount of the bond established by the municipal court for the offense. Each instance of a violation shall be considered a separate offense the amount so paid shall be forfeited unless the person appears before the municipal judge at the time fixed in the notice. A person receiving a notice of violation for animal cruelty pursuant to Section 6.20.010 or animal neglect pursuant to Section 6.20.013 shall be required to appear before the court on or before the date noted on the violation. If the person chooses to plead guilty to the violation, the court will determine the appropriate sentence at a time and date to be determined by the court. 
2.  Any person who fails to appear in court at the time fixed in the notice of violation shall be formally charged by complaint and warrant with violation of the applicable municipal ordinance and shall be brought before the court to be dealt with in accordance with law. 
(Ord. 1366 § 1, 2001; Ord. No. 1662 , § 1, 7-1-2014) 
Chapter 1.28 - GENERAL PENALTY 
Sections: 

1.28.010 - Amount-Continuing violations. 
    Whenever in this code, or in any ordinance, rule or regulation promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority vested in him or it by law or ordinance, any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful, or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this code, or any such ordinance, rule or regulation shall be punished by a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars. Each day any violation of this code or any such ordinance, rule or regulation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Prior code § 1-6; Ord. 670 § 1, 1981) 
1.28.020 - Additional costs-Disposition of fines. 
    The municipal judge in the city shall, at the end of each day, turn over to the city treasurer all fines collected. The municipal judge in the city shall submit to the city manager a monthly report of fines collected, and such report shall include an itemized statement of all fees and costs collected during the month. The municipal judge shall be responsible to the city on his official bond for all fees and fines collected by him. 
(Prior code § 1-7; Ord. 983 § 8, 1989) 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 
Chapters: 
Chapter 2.04 - CITY COUNCIL 
Sections: 

2.04.010 - Applicability of chapter. 
    This chapter covers rules and regulations on elections, vacancies, ward boundaries, official record, voting requirements and salaries. The city council shall adopt procedural rules and a code of conduct via resolution which shall govern the city council meetings. 
(Prior code § 2-8 (part); Ord. No. 1709 , § 1, 6-7-2016) 
2.04.012 - Members-Term and oath of office. 
    The city council shall consist of nine councilmembers. The councilmembers shall be elected from wards, with three members elected from each ward. The term of office of a councilmember is four years. The term of office of a person elected at the municipal general election commences on the first Monday in January following the general election. Prior to commencing the duties of office, each councilmember shall sign and file the constitutional oath of office with the city clerk. 
(Ord. 751 § 1, 1983; Ord. 1381 § 1, 2002; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
2.04.014 - Members-Vacancies-Procedure for filling. 
A.  Any vacancy on the council shall be filled in one of the following manners: 
1.  In the event the vacancy occurs as determined by council before the first day of May of an even numbered year, then notice of the vacancy shall be sent by the clerk to the county clerk that a vacancy exists and applications for nomination will be accepted, and the position is to be included on the primary and general election of that even numbered year. Appointment of a temporary successor shall then be made by council pursuant to the provisions herein, and the temporary successor shall serve until replaced in accordance with the will of the voters, or until the term expires. 
2.  In the event the vacancy occurs on or after the first day of May of an even numbered year, then the council shall appoint a temporary successor to serve for the remainder of the term of office. 
B.  A vacancy shall be deemed to have occurred when a majority of all elected councilmembers determine that a councilmember: 
1.  Is no longer a resident of the city, if an at-large representative, or of the ward from which he or she was elected, if a ward representative; 
2.  Has been convicted of a felony; 
3.  Has been determined to be insane or mentally incompetent; 
4.  Has become disqualified from holding office for any reason specified by law; 
5.  Has had his or her term expire when no successor has been elected and qualified; 
6.  Has refused to take the oath of office or to give a bond as required by law; 
7.  Has his or her election voided; 
8.  Is convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude or constituting a breach of his or her oath of office; 
9.  Has died; or 
10.  Resigns. 
C.  The Laramie city council shall determine by a majority vote of all councilmembers whether and when a vacancy occurs in the office. An abstention by any voting member of the governing body shall be considered a no vote. Upon the declaration by the city council that a vacancy exists or will exist, the council shall then publicly solicit applications from qualified electors to fill the vacancy. 
D.  Upon investigation by the council or its designated official, and the receipt of a certified copy of an order of a court of competent jurisdiction, a vacancy shall be deemed to exist with respect to subdivisions 3., 4. or 7. of subsection B. of this section. 
E.  A councilmember shall be deemed a non-resident, and a vacancy therefore to exist, when he or she shall have failed to occupy a fixed, permanent and customary place of habitation, within the boundaries of the municipality, if elected at large, or within the ward from which he or she was elected, if a ward representative, for a period of at least three hundred days during each calendar year. 
F.  A councilmember shall be deemed to have been convicted of a felony, a crime involving moral turpitude, or a breach of his or her oath of office upon receipt of a certified copy of an order of a court of competent jurisdiction showing a conviction, plea of guilty or plea of nolo contendre. 
G.  The death of a councilmember shall be evidenced by the receipt of a certified copy of a death certificate. 
H.  A resignation shall be deemed effective and a vacancy to have occurred as follows: 
1.  A councilmember desiring to resign from his or her position on the governing body shall submit a resignation in writing to the municipal clerk specifying the date he or she desires the resignation to be effective, which date shall not be more than one hundred twenty days after the postmark date of the letter, if mailed, or after the date of delivery to the municipal clerk. 
2.  The municipal clerk shall place the question of resignation before the governing body for acceptance or rejection at the regular meeting next succeeding the postmark date of the letter of resignation or the delivery thereof to the municipal clerk. 
3.  The resignation may be withdrawn at any time prior to acceptance or rejection by the governing body; provided, that a request for withdrawal of a resignation must also be in writing and received by the municipal clerk prior to the regular meeting at which the resignation is to be considered. Upon acceptance by the governing body, the resignation is irrevocable. 
4.  The resignation, unless withdrawn as stated in subdivision 3. of this subsection, shall be deemed effective as of the date specified in the written resignation. The process of filling the vacancy shall commence upon the acceptance of the resignation by the governing body and the resigning councilmember may participate in the process of filling the vacancy; provided, however, that the formal vote on the selection of an appointee shall not take place until after the effective date of the resignation. 
I.  The refusal of the mayor or a council-member to take the oath of office, as required by law, at the time and place, and before the person designated, shall constitute a failure to take the oath as required by subdivision B.6. of this section and a vacancy shall be deemed to exist at such time. 
J.  The term "qualified elector" includes every citizen of the United States who is a bona fide resident of the city, who has registered to vote and who is at least eighteen years of age. No person is a qualified elector who is a mentally incompetent person, or who has been convicted of a felony and whose civil rights have not been restored or who is otherwise barred from holding office by reason of state or federal law. 
K.  The city council shall cause public notice to be given of its intention to solicit applications to fill any vacancy on the city council. The notice shall be published in a local newspaper of general circulation on two consecutive weeks. The application shall be submitted on a form approved by the city council which form shall require that the applicant submit information establishing applicant's legal qualifications to hold office. 
L.  The council shall specify a time period for submitting applications and the council shall then review applications received and may conduct any further review of candidates deemed necessary and, by a majority vote of all councilmembers, shall appoint a temporary successor. 
(Ord. 751 § 2, 1983; Ord. 910 §§ 1-5, 1987; Ord. 941 § 1, 1988; Ord. 1381 § 12, 2002; Ord. No. 1620, § 1, 5-15-2012) 
2.04.016 - Election of officers. 
A.  The city council shall, at the first meeting in January following a general election, elect from its members a president of the city council to be the mayor and a vice-president of the city council to be the vice-mayor. The election for mayor shall be conducted by the city clerk. The city clerk shall call for nominations from each member of the city council who is present. Each member of the city council shall be permitted to nominate one person, and a nomination shall not require a second. A nominee who wishes to decline the nomination shall so state at this time. After the nomination, each member of the city council may vote for any of the nominees. If any nominee receives a majority vote of the full city council which is five councilmembers, that councilmember will be mayor. If no nominee receives a majority vote of the full council, then the full city council will vote on the two councilmembers, or more in the event of a tie, receiving the most votes. The councilmember receiving the most votes of the full city council will be mayor. In the event of a tie, the mayor will be selected in a contest by chance. The mayor elect will conduct the election of vice-mayor in the same manner described for the election of the mayor herein. 
B.  If a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor or vice-mayor, the members of city council at the next regular meeting shall select a mayor from their number for the unexpired term and shall follow the election process as outlined in subsection A herein. In the event of a vacancy, the replacement shall serve the remainder of the term vacated. 
C.  The mayor or vice-mayor can be changed anytime by a supermajority or three-fourths vote of the entire city council. 
D.  The mayor shall preside over all meetings of the city council and shall sign ordinances, resolutions, proclamations, bonds, contracts and other obligations to be signed in the name of the city. 
(Ord. 751 § 3, 1983; Ord. 1497 § 1, 2006) 
2.04.020 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1709 , § 2, adopted June 7, 2016, repealed former § 2.04.020 which pertained to suspension procedure, and derived from prior code § 2-8. 
2.04.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1709 , § 2, adopted June 7, 2016, repealed former § 2.04.030 which pertained to appointment of committees, boards and commissions, and derived from prior code § 2-9; Ord. No. 739, § 1, adopted in 1983; and Ord. No. 1297, § 1, adopted in 2000. 
2.04.031 - Definitions. 
    As defined in this chapter: 
    "Residence" is the place of a person's actual habitation. The construction of this term shall be governed by the following rules: 
1.  Residence is the place where a person has a current habitation and to which, whenever he or she is absent, he or she has the intention of returning; 
2.  A person shall not gain or lose residence merely by reason of his or her presence or absence while: 
a.  Employed in the service of the United States or of the state of Wyoming, 
b.  A student at an institution of learning, 
c.  Kept at a hospital or other institution, or 
d.  Stationed at or residing on a military reservation or installation or at a transient camp maintained for relief purposes by the government of the United States in Wyoming. No person shall be excluded as a voter solely because of his or her residence on a federal enclave within Wyoming. This factor shall be considered with all others in the determination of the person's residence within the city of Laramie and any of its wards for the purposes of voting, nomination for city council and holding a seat on city council; 
3.  A person shall not lose his or her residence by leaving his or her home to go to another state, another district of this state, another ward within the city of Laramie, or to another country for temporary purposes, with the intent of returning, if he or she has not registered in the other state, district or ward; 
4.  A person shall not gain residence in a ward if he or she enters it without the intent of making it his or her current actual residence; 
5.  If a person removes to another ward, with the intent of making it his or her residence, he or she loses his or her residence in his or her ward for the purposes of nomination for city council and holding a seat on city council as a representative of the ward from which he or she removed; 
6.  A person who takes up or continues his or her abode at a place other than where his or her family resides is a resident of the place where he or she actually abides. 
(Ord. 1381 § 2, 2002) 
2.04.032 - Members election procedure. 
A.  The council finds that the public interest is best served by having an election in each ward during the general elections held in even-numbered years in conformance with current law, and alternating between one and two members from each ward elected during those ward elections. To that end, during the general municipal election of 2012 wards one and two shall have two positions each stand for election to conform with the expiring terms of sitting councilmembers. Those positions are presently held by council members with terms expiring January, 2013, or such unfilled positions as are created by the establishment of the ward boundaries. Each previously mentioned ward has one position occupied by a councilmember whose term does not expire in 2013. Ward three shall have a single position to stand for election in 2012, with holdover positions of seated councilmembers filling the remaining two positions. 
B.  Those positions held by incumbent office holders which expire in 2015 shall be filled by election in 2014. 
C.  All positions within a ward shall be elected at large, with all eligible candidates appearing on the primary ballot, and the two candidates receiving the most votes for each available position appearing on the general election ballot. The candidate receiving the most votes for each available position shall be elected. 
(Ord. 1381 § 3, 2002; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1619, adopted April 3, 2012, changed the title of § 2.04.032 from "Members-At-large ward representative" to "Members election procedure." 
2.04.033 - Members-Eligibility. 
    To be eligible to seek nomination for city council, a person shall be a registered voter and a resident of the city of Laramie at the time of submitting the nomination petition, and a resident of the ward from which he/she seeks nomination. 
(Ord. 1381 § 4, 2002; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
2.04.034 - Ward boundaries. 
A.  Ward 1 shall include all of the property within the city limits which lies within that area bounded by the line described as follows: 
    Beginning at the point where the East rail of the Union Pacific Railroad mainline crosses the Northern limit line of the city; 
    Thence, southerly along said rail to a point where the centerline of Baker Street intersects with said rail; 
    Thence, easterly along said centerline of Baker Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of 4th Street; 
    Thence, southerly along said centerline of 4th Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of Harney Street; 
    Thence, easterly along said centerline of Harney Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of 9th Street; 
    Thence, southerly along said centerline of 9th Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of Symons Street; 
    Thence, easterly along said centerline of Symons Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the city limit; 
    Thence, southerly along said city limits to the point where said city limits reaches the point of beginning. 
B.  Ward 2 shall include all of the property within the city limits which lies within that area bounded by the line described as follows: 
    Beginning at the point where the east rail of the Union Pacific Railroad mainline crosses the Northern limit line of the city; 
    Thence, southerly along said rail to a point where the centerline of Baker Street intersects with said rail; 
    Thence, easterly along said centerline of Baker Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of 4th Street; 
    Thence, southerly along said centerline of 4th Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of Harney Street; 
    Thence, easterly along said centerline of Harney Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of 9th Street; 
    Thence, southerly along said centerline of 9th Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the centerline of Symons Street; 
    Thence, easterly along said centerline of Symons Street to the point where said centerline intersects with the city limit; 
    Thence, northerly along said city limit to the point where said city limit intersects with the centerline, or a continuation thereof, of Corthell Road on the southerly right-of-way line of Whitman Street; 
    Thence, northeasterly along the southerly right-of-way line of Whitman Street to the point where said right-of-way line intersects the east right-of-way line of Stuart Street; 
    Thence, northwesterly along the easterly right-of-way of Stuart Street to the point where such right-of-way line intersects with the southeasterly right-of-way line of Ashley Street; 
    Thence, northeasterly along the southeasterly right-of-way line of Ashley Street to the point where such right-of-way line intersects with the northerly right-of-way line of Hillside Drive; 
    Thence, westerly along the northerly right-of-way line of Hillside Drive to the point where such right-of-way line intersects with the easterly right-of-way line of Bonneville Street; 
    Thence, northerly along the easterly right-of-way line of Bonneville Street to the point where said right-of-way line intersects with the northerly right-of-way line of Holiday Street; 
    Thence, northwesterly along the northerly right-of-way line of Holiday Drive to the point where said right-of-way line of Holiday Drive, or a continuation thereof, intersects the centerline of Corthell Road; 
    Thence, northwesterly along the centerline of Corthell Road to the point where such centerline intersects with the centerline of Sheridan Street; 
    Thence, westerly along the centerline of Sheridan Street to the point where such centerline intersects with the centerline of 15th Street: 
    Thence northerly along the centerline of 15th Street to the point where such centerline intersects with the city limits; 
    Thence, westerly along the city limits to the point where the city limits intersects with the east rail of the Union Pacific mainline, the point of beginning. 
C.  Ward 3 shall include all of the property within the city limits which lies within that line described as follows: 
    Beginning at the point where city limit line, on a continuation of the centerline of Corthell Road, intersects the southerly right-of-way line of Whitman Street; 
    Thence, northeasterly along the centerline of Whitman Street to the point where said centerline intersects the centerline of Holiday Drive; 
    Thence, northwesterly along the centerline of Holiday Drive to the point where said centerline of Holiday Drive intersects the centerline of Corthell Road; 
    Thence, northwesterly along the centerline of Corthell Road to the point where such centerline intersects with the centerline of Sheridan Street; 
    Thence, westerly along the centerline of Sheridan Street to the point where such centerline intersects with the centerline of 15th Street: 
    Thence northerly along the centerline of 15th Street to the point where such centerline intersects with the city limits; 
    Thence, easterly along the city limits to the point where city limit line intersects the southerly right-of-way line of Whitman Street, the point of beginning. 
(Ord. 1381 § 5, 2002; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
2.04.035 - Term of office. 
    Every councilmember shall be elected for a four-year term, with the exception of a member appointed to fill an unexpired term of office and being required to run for office in the ensuing election under the provisions of W.S. ch. 15-11. 
(Ord. 1381 § 6, 2002; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1619, adopted April 3, 2012, changed the title of § 2.04.035 from "At-large ward representative-Term of office" to "Term of office." 
2.04.036 - Ward representation. 
    All councilmembers must reside in the ward from which they were elected or appointed for not less than one year prior to election to represent that ward. 
(Ord. 1381 § 7, 2002; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1619, adopted April 3, 2012, changed the title of § 2.04.036 from "At-large ward representative-Represent wards" to "Ward representation." 
2.04.037 - Vacancies in office. 
A.  Any vacancy in the office of a councilmember shall be filled from the ward from which the councilmember was elected, with the same eligibility requirements as may be found for persons seeking office by election. The selection of the person shall be made by the council pursuant to ordinance requirements. 
B.  Any person appointed to fill an unexpired term of office may serve that unexpired term until his successor is elected at the next general election and is qualified for the office. Persons appointed at a date too late to have his name placed on the ballot of the general election by the city clerk shall serve until his replacement is elected and seated in the following general election. 
(Ord. 1381 § 8, 2002; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1619, adopted April 3, 2012, changed the title of § 2.04.037 from "At-large ward representative-Candidates" to "Vacancies in office." 
2.04.038 - Wards-Census data. 
    The wards described in Section 2.04.034 are based upon the census data for the year 2010. For any territory which is not included in the ward description, but is annexed to the city thereafter, the territory shall be included within the ward with which it shares the longest common boundary, unless the territory is allocated between two wards at the passage of the ordinance annexing the territory. 
(Ord. 1381 § 9, 2002; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
2.04.039 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1619, adopted April 3, 2012, repealed § 2.04.039, which pertained to members-ward representatives-vacancy, and derived from Ord. No. 1381, § 10, adopted in 2002. 
2.04.040 - Claims against city must go through a committee. 
    No bills or claims against the city shall be allowed until acted upon and reported by a committee. 
(Prior code § 2-10) 
2.04.070 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1709 , § 2, adopted June 7, 2016, repealed former § 2.04.070 which pertained to parliamentary procedure, and derived from prior code § 2-12. 
2.04.080 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1709 , § 2, adopted June 7, 2016, repealed former § 2.04.080 which pertained to public meetings-exception-journal of proceedings, and derived from prior code § 2-13. 
2.04.085 - Minutes of city council meetings are official record. 
    The journal of minutes of the proceedings of city council meetings, as approved with or without correction by minute action of the council at a later meeting, are the official record of all matters reported therein. If there is any variance between the approved minutes and any record of the proceedings made by electronic, stenographic, or other means, then the approved minutes control. 
(Ord. 1109 § 1, 1993)

Editor's note- Ord. No. 1709 , § 2, adopted June 7, 2016, repealed former § 2.04.090 which pertained to quorum, and derived from prior code § 2-14.

2.04.200 - Councilmen required to vote-Exceptions. 
    Each councilman who is present when a question is to be voted upon shall vote thereon, unless excused therefrom by the city council. He may, before the vote is called for, give his reasons for not voting. If he is directly interested in the question he need not vote. When he is on trial he shall not vote. 
(Prior code § 2-25) 
2.04.210 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1709 , § 2, adopted June 7, 2016, repealed former § 2.04.210 which pertained to motions to reconsider-procedure, and derived from prior code § 2-26; and Ord. No. 917, § 1, adopted in 1988.

2.04.240 - Council member salaries. 
    Council members, including the mayor, shall be paid one hundred twenty dollars for actual attendant at each regular meeting and special meeting and work session and public hearing of the Laramie City Council when held on separate days. 
(Ord. No. 1536, § 1, 9-16-2008) 
Editor's note- Charter Ord. No. 6, adopted on Sept. 16, 2008, repealed former § 2.04.020 which pertained to the salaries of positions fixed by city council and derived from Charter Ord. No. 1, adopted in 1978. 
Charter Ord. No. 7, adopted on Sept. 16, 2008, repealed former § 2.04.250 which pertained to the salaries of council members and derived from Charter Ord. No. 4, §§ 1, 2, 2000; Charter Ord. No. 5, §§ 1, 2, 2001. 
Chapter 2.08 - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
Sections: 

2.08.010 - Appointment of officers. 
    The city council shall by a majority vote of its members, appoint persons for the position of city manager, city attorney and municipal judge. The city manager, city attorney and municipal judge shall serve at the pleasure of the city council and their employment may be terminated at any time by a vote of the majority of the members of the city council. The city council shall decide annually to conduct a job performance evaluation of the persons serving as city manager, city attorney and municipal judge. 
(Ord. 620 § 1, 1980; Ord. 913 § 1, 1988) 
2.08.020 - Employment by city manager-Exceptions. 
    Except for the city attorney and municipal judge, all employees shall be employed by the city manager and be selected on merit and serve at his pleasure. The city council may from time to time appoint such assistants as it deems necessary for the city attorney and the municipal judge. 
(Ord. 620 § 2, 1980) 
2.08.025 - Authority of city manager. 
    The city manager or city manager's designees shall have the authority to direct and deploy city staff, employees, equipment and resources to fulfill the obligations of the city under any contract, agreement, grant, resolution or other city obligation approved by council, and the obligations of the city under any applicable statute. 
(Ord. No. 1729 , 4-18-2017) 
2.08.030 - Bonds-Required for officers. 
    Upon assuming the duties of the office of clerk-treasurer or city treasurer, the officer shall give a bond to the city in the amount of fifty thousand dollars. All other officers and employees of the city shall be bonded by a blanket position bond in an amount not less than ten thousand dollars. 
(Prior code § 2-4 (part)) 
2.08.040 - Bonds-Description. 
    Such bonds shall be bonds of a surety company and shall be approved by the city council and filed with the city clerk. The cost of such bonds shall be paid by the city. Such bonds shall be conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties required by law and by this code and other ordinances of the city pertaining to their respective offices. 
(Prior code § 2-4 (part)) 
2.08.050 - Duties-Generally. 
    Councilmen shall attend all meetings of the city council and shall lend such aid and assistance in the direction and management of the city government as may be necessary under the Charter, the laws of the state and this code and other ordinances of the city. All other officers and employees of the city shall perform the duties required of them by the city manager, the laws of the state and this code and other ordinances of the city, as the same may pertain to them. 
(Prior code § 2-5) 
2.08.060 - Responsibility for city property.
