(viii)  The city manager or designee may reduce the maximum allowable axle loads and gross weight limits for specific highways, streets, alleys, boxes, or sections thereof or for bridges within the city if in the opinion of the city manager the continued operation of vehicles or combinations of vehicles would create undue damage to the highways or bridges. Any person owning or operating a vehicle or combination of vehicles in violation of reduced load limits when posted or otherwise appropriately marked is liable for damage to the highway, street, alley, box or bridge in question in addition to the penalties provided by law; 
(ix)  There is no obligation on the city to heighten any bridge, tunnel or other structure on highways because of the provisions of this act. The city manager or designee may reduce the size and weight limits of vehicles and loads on state and federal highways if, in his discretion, road conditions require. 
(Ord. 1081 § 2, 1993) 
12.18.030 - Size and weight limits. 
    Legal load limits for all streets, alleys, bridges, boxes and other structures shall be as specified in Sections 12.18.010 and 12.18.020. 
(Ord. 1081 § 3, 1993) 
12.18.040 - Maximum weight limits. 
    The city manager or his designee is authorized to establish load limits for all bridges, boxes, and other structures owned by the city. Load limits may be less than the standard legal load limit to protect the bridge, box, or other structure. Where the load limit is less than the legal load limit, adequate signs will be posted at each end of the bridge, box or other structure indicating the maximum weight allowed for each class of truck. 
(Ord. 1081 § 4, 1993) 
12.18.050 - Permission for moving oversize loads. 
A.  Any person who wishes to move an oversize load on city streets, highways, or alleys shall submit a written request for permission for the one-time movement of an oversize load to the city manager. The request shall be accompanied with a map showing the proposed route. 
B.  The city manager or designee may approve the request, may grant the request with conditions which in the opinion of the city manager or designee will protect the streets, alleys, highways, bridges, boxes, or other structures, or may deny the request. Approval, conditional approval, or denial shall be in writing. 
C.  Approval or conditional approval by the city manager does not relieve the applicant of the duty to obey the laws of the state of Wyoming concerning movement on highways. 
D.  Any person who moves an oversize load within the city limits on city streets, highways, or alleys shall do so along the route shown on the map submitted with the application and the person shall have written approval for the movement being made, signed by the city manager or designee, in his or her immediate possession. If the approval was conditional, no person shall move an oversize load within the city limits except in conformity to the conditions of approval. 
E.  The request for permission shall be upon a form prescribed by the city manager and shall be accompanied by a fee of ten dollars. The request for permission shall contain a description of the vehicle or combination, the proposed route, the date of movement, and such other information as the city manager shall require. 
F.  The city manager or his designee shall grant permission in a written permit if he finds that the required information is given and that granting the permit is in the public interest. The city manager or his designee is not responsible to determine whether the proposed movement may be made in safety. 
G.  A permit is valid for the vehicle or combination described therein upon the route described therein for a single movement from one specified location to another. 
H.  No holder of a permit shall move any oversize/overweight vehicle or combination which is not listed in a valid permit, nor may the equipment depart from the route specified in the permit. 
I.  No holder of a permit is permitted to disregard or fail to obey any lawful order of the city manager or designee under Section 12.18.020(a)(viii) or any other section of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1081 § 5, 1993; Ord. 1092 § 1, 1993) 
12.18.060 - Blanket permit for routine movements. 
A.  Any person who has a principal place of business in the county may apply for a blanket permit for routine movements of oversize/overweight construction and demolition equipment. A blanket permit shall not apply to over the road trucks. 
B.  The application shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city manager and shall contain at least this information: name of the person, list of all pieces of equipment which the person wishes to be permitted to move under the blanket permit, and the person's signed agreement to keep a record of all oversize/overweight moves by date, route, weight, and item moved. The application shall be accompanied by payment of a fifty-dollar permit fee. 
C.  The city manager or his designee shall grant the blanket permit if he finds that the person has a principal place of business in the county and the required information is given. 
D.  Each blanket permittee shall keep a complete record of all oversize/overweight movements made within the city, including date, route, item moved, and weight. Each permittee shall make the record of oversize/overweight movements available for inspection by the city manager or his designee at its principal place of business during normal business hours. 
E.  If any permittee fails to keep a complete record under subsection D. of this section, or refuses to permit inspection of the record by an authorized city employee upon request, the city manager may revoke the permit upon five days' notice. The holder of a revoked blanket permit is not eligible to apply for another blanket permit during the calendar year of revocation. 
F.  A blanket permit is valid for the calendar year in which it is issued. 
G.  No holder of a blanket permit shall move any oversize/overweight load which is not listed in the permit. 
H.  No holder of a blanket permit is permitted to disregard or fail to obey any lawful order of the city manager or designee under Sections 12.18.020(a)(viii), 12.18.040 or 12.18.050. 
(Ord. 1081 § 6, 1993) 
12.18.070 - Enforcement. 
A.  The driver of any vehicle, or combination of vehicles upon demand of any law enforcement officer who has reason to believe that the weight of any vehicle or combination, including load, if any, is unlawful, shall stop and submit the vehicle or combination of vehicles and any load thereon to a weighing at any state owned or leased scales or other certified scales selected by the officer and not to exceed five miles from the point of stop unless the vehicle has been weighed at a port of entry with the same load and the driver displays the weight ticket to the officer upon request. The driver shall comply with the directions of the officer to obtain the total weight or measurement of the load and vehicle. 
B.  If a vehicle or combination of vehicles does not exceed the gross weight provisions of Table I or Table II of Section 12.18.020, but does exceed the axle limits in an amount not over two thousand pounds, the cargo may be repositioned by the operator to comply with the legal limits and be allowed to proceed without penalty. 
(Ord. 1081 § 7, 1993) 
12.18.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Upon conviction of a violation of this chapter, the violator shall be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars for each offense. 
(Ord. 1081 § 8, 1993) 
Division II. - Construction 
Chapter 12.20 - CLOSURE AUTHORITY 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - Public ways-Barricades. 
    The city manager is authorized to temporarily close any street, alley or other public way or portion thereof, while such street is undergoing construction, alteration or repair or being involved with any special work, either by the city on account of its own work, contractors performing services for the city or public utilities or franchise holders legally working thereon. In closing such street, alley or public way, the city manager shall cause to be erected appropriate barricades, signs and warnings sufficient to fairly appraise the public thereof. 
(Prior code § 34-15) 
Chapter 12.24 - EXCAVATIONS 
Sections: 
Article I. - General Provisions 

12.24.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
A.  "Administrative authority" means the city engineer or his authorized representative. 
B.  "Excavation" means any opening in the surface of a public place made in any manner whatsoever, except an opening into a lawful structure below the surface of a public place, the top of which is flush with the adjoining surface and so constructed as to permit frequent openings without injury or damage to the public place. 
C.  "Facility" means pipe, pipeline, tube, main, service, trap, vent, vault, manhole, meter, gauge, regulator, valve, conduit, wire, tower, pole, pole line, anchor, cable, junction box, transformer or any other material, structure or object of any kind or character, whether enumerated in this section or not, which is or may be lawfully constructed, left, placed or maintained in, upon, along, across, under or over any public place. 
D.  "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
E.  "Public place" means any public street, way, place, alley, sidewalk, park, square, plaza or any other public property owned or controlled by any governmental agency in a governmental capacity. 
F.  "Substructure" means any pipe, conduit, duct, tunnel, manhole, vault, buried cable or wire or any other structure located below the surface of any public place. 
(Prior code § 34-18; Ord. 844 § 1, 1985) 
12.24.020 - Administrative authority-Inspections. 
    The administrative authority shall make such inspections as are reasonably necessary in the enforcement of this chapter. The administrative authority shall have the authority to promulgate and cause to be enforced such rules and regulations as may be reasonably necessary to enforce and carry out the intent of this chapter. All work for which a permit is required is subject to inspection and approval by the administrative authority. The permit applicant shall cause the work to remain accessible and exposed for inspection purposes, and shall notify the administrative authority when the work is ready for inspection. Continuous inspection may be required by the administrative authority during backfilling operations. Approval as a result of an inspection shall not be construed to be an approval of a violation of the provisions of this chapter or of other city ordinances. Neither the administrative authority or the city shall be liable for expense entailed in the removal or replacement of any material required to allow inspection. The administrative authority shall have the authority to determine such fees as may be reasonable for the cost of restoration and inspections. Such fees will be prominently displayed on the permit application. 
(Prior code § 34-19; Ord. 844 § 2, 1985; Ord. 1088 § 1, 1992) 
12.24.030 - Maximum length of open trenches. 
    The maximum length of open trench permissible at any time shall be in accordance with this code and other existing ordinances or regulations as may be specified by the administrative authority and no greater length shall be open for pavement removal, excavation, construction, backfilling, patching or any other operations without the written permission of the administrative authority. 
(Prior code § 34-41) 
12.24.040 - Emergency excavations. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the making of such excavations as may be necessary for the preservation of life or property or for making emergency repairs outside of normal working hours; provided, that the person making such excavation shall apply to the administrative authority for an excavation permit on the first working day after such work is commenced; and further, that the city police, fire, and street departments shall be notified before the excavation of the intent to excavate and the reason for doing so. Only work necessary to satisfy the need that constitutes the excavation as an emergency shall be done before obtaining a permit as outlined in this chapter. No backfill or restoration shall be done until an investigation has been conducted by the administrative authority. If in the opinion of the administrative authority the excavation should not have been classified as an emergency excavation, an investigation fee, in addition to the permit fee, shall be collected whether or not a permit is then or subsequently issued. The investigation fee shall be established by the administrative authority in accordance with Sections 12.24.020 and 12.24.080. 
(Prior code § 34-51; Ord. 844 § 3, 1985; Ord. 1088 § 2, 1992) 
12.24.050 - City and city employees not liable. 
    This chapter shall not be construed as imposing upon the city or any official or employee thereof any liability or responsibility for damages to any person injured or property damaged by the performance of any excavation work for which an excavation permit is issued, nor shall the city or any official or employee thereof be deemed to have assumed any such liability or responsibility by reason of inspections authorized under this chapter, the issuance of any permit or the approval of any excavation work. 
(Prior code § 3-52; Ord. 844 § 4, 1985) 
Article II. - Permits 

12.24.060 - Required-Annual blanket permit. 
    No person shall make any excavation or fill any excavation in any public place without first obtaining a permit to do so from the administrative authority, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. Whenever any work for which a permit is required by this code has been commenced without first obtaining said permit, except emergencies as provided for under Section 12.24.040, the work may be stopped and a special investigation made before a permit is issued for such work. An investigation fee, in addition to the permit fee, shall be collected whether or not a permit is then or subsequently issued. The investigation fee shall be established by the administrative authority in accordance with Sections 12.24.020 and 12.24.080. No permit to make an excavation or fill an excavation in a public place shall be issued except as provided in this chapter. No permit to make an excavation or fill in a public place shall be issued for newly paved, repaved, constructed or reconstructed streets for a period of two years after the initial paving, repaving, construction or reconstruction of the street, except as provided for emergency repairs in this chapter. In the case of newly platted and constructed subdivisions, the two-year period shall begin on the date of final acceptance of such subdivisions. In the event that additional underground utilities are needed through such streets, the permittee will be required to bore or tunnel such streets in a manner approved by the administrative authority in order to provide such utilities. In the event that additional underground utilities are needed in such streets, the permittee may make such excavation as required, provided: 
A.  Such excavation has been approved by the administrative authority: and 
B.  The permit fee for such excavation shall include a penalty fee equal to three times the amount of the normal restoration fee for the first one hundred fifty square feet of ditch restoration, and two times the normal restoration fee for each square foot thereafter, in addition to the restoration fee paid; and 
C.  In the case of newly platted and constructed subdivisions, prior to the date of final acceptance of such subdivisions, street cuts shall be approved in writing by the administrative authority and a penalty fee for such cuts shall be assessed at a rate equal to five times the amount of the normal restoration fee for the first one hundred fifty square feet of ditch restoration and three times the normal restoration fee for each square foot thereafter. Specific approval and penalty fee shall not be required when the excavation is for the purpose of raising to final street grade manholes and water valves on water mains. No restoration fee or permit fee shall be assessed in such cases, and all restoration shall be executed by the subdivider. 
    The administrative authority may issue an annual blanket permit for the purpose of placing, replacing or repairing any facility within a public place to: 
A.  A public utility regulated by the Public Utilities Commission of the state; 
B.  A person holding a franchise from the city; 
C.  Appropriate departments of the city and county as determined by the administrative authority. 
(Prior code § 34-20; Ord. 844 § 5, 1985; Ord. 1088 § 3, 1992) 
12.24.070 - Application-Contents. 
    No excavation permit shall be issued unless a written application, made on a form or forms provided by the administrative authority, for the issuance of an excavation permit is submitted to the administrative authority. The written application shall state the name and address, principal place of business, and business telephone of the applicant. The application shall also state the purpose for which the applicant desires to occupy the public place for which the permit is sought, the location and dimensions of the installation or removal for which the excavation is to be made, the purpose of the facility, the dimensions of the proposed excavation, the date that the excavation is to commence, and the length of time which will be required to complete such work, including backfilling such excavation and removing all obstructions, material and debris. The application, when approved and signed by the administrative authority, shall constitute a permit. 
    Public utilities regulated by the Public Utilities Commission of the state, persons holding a franchise from the city, and appropriate departments of the city and county who are holders of current annual blanket permits by the administrative authority shall be exempt from the requirement to submit written application for the issuance of individual excavation permits; provided, that all excavation work performed under the auspices of the blanket permit shall be performed by the organization's official employees, that the administrative authority be notified in advance of such excavation and that all fees are current as determined by the administrative authority. Persons performing work for the organizations on a contract or subcontract basis shall be required to submit written application for excavation permits. Every permit issued by the administrative authority under the provisions of this code shall expire and become null and void if the work authorized by such permit is not commenced within one hundred twenty days from the date of such permit. A separate permit shall be obtained for each excavation. 
(Prior code § 34-21; Ord. 844 § 6, 1985; Ord. 1088 § 4, 1992) 
12.24.080 - Fee. 
    A permit fee shall be charged by the administrative authority for the issuance of an excavation permit. The fee for a permit shall be ten dollars. Additional payment or deposit of funds to defray costs of restoration and inspection may be required as outlined in other provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 34-22; Ord. 844 § 7, 1985) 
12.24.090 - Insurance-Required. 
    Before an excavation permit is issued, the applicant therefor shall file a certificate of insurance evidencing the fact that the applicant has purchased and has in effect an insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state, providing for public liability and property damage coverage in the sum of five hundred thousand dollars, combined single limit coverage, to protect the applicant and the city from any expense, cost, damage, and any liability of any kind or character whatsoever, resulting from or which may arise as a result of the applicant's opening any street under a permit issued hereunder or which may in any way be connected therewith or relating thereto. The insurance policy shall be continuous until cancelled. The insurance shall provide that the city shall receive twenty days' notice by registered mail, in advance of such cancellation. 
(Prior code § 34-23 (part); Ord. 844 § 8, 1985) 
12.24.100 - Insurance-Authority to waive requirement. 
    Public utilities operating under the supervision of the Public Utilities Commission, public utilities holding a franchise from the city, appropriate city departments, and other governmental agencies may be relieved of the obligation of submitting such insurance by the administrative authority. 
(Prior code § 34-23 (part); Ord. 844 § 9, 1985) 
12.24.110 - Notice to be given after issuance. 
    The excavation permit issued by the administrative authority may require that the permittee give notification to various public agencies and to the general public. In such case, such permit shall not be valid until such notice is given. 
(Prior code § 34-26 (part)) 
Article III. - Public Convenience and Safety 

12.24.120 - Barriers and warning devices. 
A.  It shall be the duty of every person, making an excavation in or upon any public place, to place and maintain such barriers and warning devices as may be necessary for safety. The permittee is responsible for providing adequate devices to alert the public, motorists and pedestrians of hazardous conditions in accordance with the current Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices as published by the U.S. Department of Transportation, or as otherwise specifically approved in writing by the administrative authority. A traffic control plan shall be submitted with all permit applications submitted for excavations in streets designated as collector or arterial and the traffic control plan shall be approved before the permit is issued. 
B.  In the discretion of the administrative authority, failure to comply with the requirements for traffic control may result in immediate stoppage of the work and such work shall not recommence until the requirements have been met and approved by the administrative authority. 
(Prior code § 34-25 (part); Ord. 844 § 10 1985; Ord. 1088 § 5, 1992) 
12.24.140 - Disturbance of traffic-Street closures. 
    A permittee under this chapter shall take appropriate measures to assure that during the performance of the excavation work, traffic conditions as nearly normal as practicable shall be maintained at all times so as to cause as little inconvenience as possible to the occupants of the abutting property and to the general public; provided, that the administrative authority may permit the closing of streets and alleys to all traffic for period of time prescribed by him, if in his opinion it is necessary. The written approval of the administrative authority may require that the permittee give notification to such public agencies as he deems necessary; provided, however, that in no case shall a street or alley be closed without prior notification to the city police, fire and street departments. The administrative authority may require that prior notification be given to the general public. Approval for closing of a street or alley shall not be valid until all required notification has been made. 
(Prior code § 34-26 (part); Ord. 844 § 12, 1985) 
12.24.150 - Maintenance of safe crossings. 
    A permittee under this chapter shall maintain safe crossings for two lanes of vehicle traffic at all street intersections, where possible, and safe crossings for pedestrians at intervals of not more than three hundred feet. If any excavation is made across any public street, alley or sidewalk, at least one safe crossing shall be maintained, when possible, for vehicles and pedestrians. If the street is not made enough to hold the excavated material without using part of the adjacent sidewalk, a passageway at least one half of the sidewalk width shall be maintained along such sidewalk line. Passageways may be omitted with the specific written approval of the administrative authority. 
(Prior code § 34-27; Ord. 844 § 13, 1985) 
12.24.160 - Annoyance to public-Off-hours reduction. 
    Each permittee under this chapter shall conduct and carry out excavation work in such manner as to avoid unnecessary inconvenience and annoyance to the general public and occupants of neighboring property. The permittee shall take appropriate measures to reduce, to the fullest extent practicable in the performance of the excavation work, noise, dust and unsightly debris, and during the hours of seven p.m. to seven a.m., shall not use, except with the written permission of the administrative authority or, in case of an emergency, as otherwise provided in this chapter, any tool, appliance or equipment producing noise of sufficient volume to disturb the sleep or repose of occupants of neighboring property. All work shall be conducted and carried out in compliance with all applicable provisions of the code. 
(Prior code § 34-28; Ord. 844 § 14, 1985) 
12.24.170 - Work around the clock-Imposition authority. 
    If in his judgment, traffic condition, the safety or conveniences of the traveling public or the public interest require that the excavation work be performed as emergency work, the administrative authority shall have full power to order, at the time the permit for excavation work is granted, that a crew of men and adequate facilities be employed by the permittee twenty-four hours a day to the end that such excavation work may be completed as soon as possible. 
(Prior code § 34-24) 
12.24.180 - Prompt completion and restoration. 
    After an excavation is commenced, the permittee under this chapter shall prosecute with diligence and expedition all excavation work covered by the excavation permit and shall promptly complete such work and restore the street to its original condition or as near as may be, so as not to obstruct the public place or travel thereon more than is reasonably necessary. 
(Prior code § 34-43) 
12.24.190 - Interference with hydrant access-Prohibited. 
    All excavation work under this chapter shall be performed and conducted so as not to interfere with access to fire hydrants, fire stations, fire escapes, water gates, underground vaults, valve housing structures or any other vital equipment as designated by the administrative authority. The administrative authority may grant exemption from this section; provided, that in his opinion, the work cannot be properly performed without such exemption; and provided further, that special notice shall be given to the police, fire and street departments of designated equipment and appurtenances to be interfered with. 
(Prior code § 34-29; Ord. 844 § 15, 1985) 
12.24.200 - Safety precautions. 
    The permittee shall be responsible for initiating, maintaining and supervising all safety precautions and programs in connection with the work. The permittee shall take all necessary precautions for the safety of, and shall provide the necessary protection to prevent damage, injury or loss to all employees on the work and other persons who may be affect thereby, and other property at the site or adjacent thereto, including trees, shrubs, lawns, walks, pavements, roadways, structures and utilities not to be removed, relocated or replaced in the course of excavation, construction and restoration. 
(Prior code § 34-50; Ord. 844 § 16, 1985) 
12.24.210 - Disposition of excavated material-Generally. 
    All material excavated from trenches and piled adjacent to the trench or in any street shall be piled and maintained in such a manner as not to endanger those working in the trench, pedestrians or other users of the streets and so that as little inconvenience as possible is caused to those using streets and adjoining property. Permittee may be required to locate and separate excavated material as directed by the administrative authority. Where the confines of the area being excavated are too narrow to permit the piling of excavated material beside the trench, such as might be the case in a narrow alley, the administrative authority shall have the power to require that the permittee under this chapter haul the excavated material to a storage site and then rehaul it to the trench site at the time of backfilling. It shall be the permittee's responsibility to secure the necessary permission and make all necessary arrangements for all required storage and disposal sites. 
(Prior code § 34-36 (part); Ord. 844 § 17, 1985) 
12.24.220 - Disposition of excavated material-Toe boards. 
    All materials excavated shall be laid compactly along the side of the trench and kept trimmed so as to cause as little inconvenience as reasonably possible to vehicular and pedestrian traffic or as specified by the administrative authority. Whenever necessary, in order to expedite the flow of traffic or to abate the dirt or dust nuisance, toe boards or bins may be required by the administrative authority to prevent the spreading of dirt into traffic lanes. 
(Prior code § 34-36 (part)) 
Article IV. - Property Damage 

12.24.230 - Disturbance of monuments-Permission required. 
    Any monument set for the purpose of locating or preserving the lines of any street or property subdivision or a precise survey reference point or a permanent survey bench mark within the city shall not be removed or disturbed or caused to be removed or disturbed during any excavation, without first obtaining permission in writing from the administrative authority to do so. Permission to remove or disturb such monuments, reference points or bench marks shall only be granted upon condition that the person applying for such permission pays all expenses incident to the proper replacement of this monument by the administrative authority. 
(Prior code § 34-30) 
12.24.240 - Relocation and protection-Permittee's responsibility. 
    A permittee under this chapter shall not interfere with any existing facility without the written consent of the administrative authority and the owner of the facility. If it becomes necessary to relocate an existing facility, this shall be done by its owner. No facility owned by the city shall be moved to accommodate the permittee unless the cost of such work is borne by the permittee. The cost of moving privately owned facilities shall be similarly borne by the permittee, unless he makes other arrangements with the person owning the facility. The permittee shall support and protect by timbers or otherwise, all pipes, conduits, poles, wires or other apparatus which may be in any way affected by the excavation work and do everything necessary to support, sustain and protect them under, over, along or across such work. In case any of such pipes, conduits, poles, wires or apparatus should be damaged, and for this purpose pipe coating or other encasement or devices are to be considered as part of a substructure, they shall be repaired by the person owning them and the expense of such repairs shall be charged to the permittee and his securities shall be liable therefor. The permittee shall be responsible for any damage done to any public or private property by reason of the breaking of any water pipes, sewer, gas pipe, electric conduit or other facility and his securities shall be liable therefor. The permittee -shall inform himself as to the existence and location of all underground facilities and protect same against damage, and shall, as is practicable, inform all persons owning and/or operating such facilities of his intent to excavate. 
(Prior code § 34-31; Ord. 844 § 18, 1985) 
12.24.250 - Protection-Adjoining property. 
    A permittee under this chapter shall at all times and at his own expense preserve and protect from injury any adjoining property by providing proper foundations and taking other measures suitable for that purpose. Where in the protection of such property it is necessary to enter upon private property for the purpose of taking appropriate protective measures, the permittee shall obtain a license from the owner of such private property for such purpose, and if he cannot obtain a license from such owner, the administrative authority may authorize him to enter the private premises solely for the purpose of making the property safe. 
(Prior code § 34-32 (part)) 
12.24.260 - Protection-At permittee's expense. 
    The permittee shall, at his own expense, shore up and protect all buildings, walls, fences or other property likely to be damaged during the progress of the excavation work and shall be responsible for all damage to public or private property or highways resulting from his failure to properly protect and carry out such work. 
(Prior code § 34-32 (part)) 
12.24.270 - Lawns and parkings. 
    Whenever it may be necessary for a permittee under this chapter to trench through any lawn area, the sod shall be carefully cut and rolled and replaced after ditches have been backfilled as required in this chapter. All construction and maintenance work shall be done in a manner calculated to leave the lawn area clean of earth and debris and in a condition as near as possible to that which existed before such work began. The permittee shall not remove, even temporarily, any trees or shrubs which exist in parking strip areas without first obtaining the consent of the appropriate city department or city official having control of such property. 
(Prior code § 34-33) 
12.24.280 - Sheeting and bracing-Permittee liable for undermining. 
    All trench excavations shall be properly sheeted and braced where necessary, to prevent caving, slipping or cracking of sides. Sheeting and bracing used to support the sides of the opening shall be carefully removed as the backfilling of the trench progresses, but if considered, by the administrative authority, necessary for the protection of the banks, the sheeting and bracing shall be cut off two feet below the surface of the subgrade and left in place. If pavement along the sides of the opening is or becomes undermined and unsupported, the permittee under this chapter shall, at his own cost and expense, break down and remove such undermined pavement and the foundation thereof and shall remove all loose earth and replace with earth which is properly compacted in the manner provided in Article V. of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 34-34) 
12.24.290 - Breaking through pavement. 
    The following provisions shall be applicable where any excavation requires breaking through pavement: 
A.  Heavy duty pavement breakers may be prohibited by the administrative authority when the use endangers existing substructures or other property. 
B.  Saw cutting of portland cement concrete may be required by the administrative authority when the nature of the job or the condition of the street warrants. When required, the depth of the cut shall be not less than one inch; however, depths greater than one inch may be required by the administrative authority when circumstances warrant. Saw cutting may be required by the administrative authority outside of the limits of the excavation over cave-outs, overbreaks and small floating sections. 
C.  Approved cutting of bituminous pavement surface ahead of excavations may be required by the administrative authority to confine pavement damage to the limits of the trench. 
D.  Sections of sidewalks shall be removed to the nearest score line or saw cut edge. 
E.  Unstable pavement shall be removed over cave-outs and overbreaks and the subgrade shall be treated as the main trench. 
F.  Pavement edges shall be trimmed to a vertical face and neatly aligned with the centerline of the trench. 
G.  Cutouts outside of the trench lines must be normal or parallel to the trench line. 
H.  Boring or other methods to prevent cutting of new pavement may be required by the administrative authority. 
I.  A permitttee under this chapter shall not be required to repair damage existing prior to excavation done by him unless his cut results in small floating sections that may be unstable, in which case the permittee shall remove such sections and prepare the surface for paving. 
(Prior code § 34-35; Ord. 844 § 19, 1985) 
Article V. - Backfilling 

12.24.300 - Generally. 
    Fine material, free from lumps, stone, and organic material, selected from the spoil shall be thoroughly compacted around and under the substructure to the upper level of such substructure. Special bedding material may be required by the administrative authority, when, in his opinion, the situation warrants such material. Above the upper level of the substructure, backfill material shall be placed in the subgrade of the pavement in lifts consistent with the type of soil involved and the method of consolidation being used. Broken pavement, large stones, roots, snow, ice, frozen chunks and other deleterious material shall not be used in the backfill. In the event that material is required to be imported, the imported material shall meet the requirements stated herein for backfill. Each lift shall be flooded, jetted, rolled or tamped or a combination of these methods used, depending upon the type of soil involved, to compact the backfill material. Flooding and jetting shall be permitted only upon the written approval of the administrative authority. Such backfill shall be done in a manner that will permit the restoration of the surface to condition equivalent to that in which it was prior to excavation. 
(Prior code § 34-42 (part); Ord. 844 § 20, 1985) 
Editor's note- For further provisions on substructures, see Chapter 12.28. 
12.24.310 - Soil tests. 
    The administrative authority may require soil tests to be furnished by a recognized soil testing laboratory or registered professional engineer specializing in soil mechanics when in his opinion backfill for any excavation is not being adequately compacted. In order for resurfacing to be permitted, such tests must show that the backfill material and degree of compaction obtained meets the minimum requirements as prescribed by the administrative authority. All expenses of such tests and any work required to assure adequate compaction of the backfill shall be borne by the permittee. 
(Prior code § 34-42 (part); Ord. 844 § 21, 1985) 
12.24.320 - Notice of completion. 
    Upon completion of backfilling, a permittee under this chapter shall notify the administrative authority that surface restoration may be made. 
(Prior code § 34-44) 
Article VI. - Surface Restoration 

12.24.330 - Generally. 
    Permanent resurfacing of excavations may be made where the type of consolidation used in replacing the backfill is adequate, in the opinion of the administrative authority, to prevent settling and when the moisture content of the backfill is not excessive. In the event the type of consolidation used in replacing the backfill is not adequate to prevent further settling or the moisture content is excessive, temporary resurfacing shall be provided. If temporary surfacing is provided, the top surface of the backfill shall be covered with bituminous material at the following minimum thicknesses: 
A.  One inch in sidewalk locations: 
B.  Two inches wherever excavation is made through pavement, alley approaches or driveways; 
C.  At major intersections and other critical locations a greater thickness may be ordered by the administrative authority. 
    Such temporary paving material shall be cold mix, except that the permittee may use or the administrative authority may require hot mix. All temporary paving material shall conform closely enough to the level of the adjoining paving surface and shall be compacted so that it is hard enough and smooth enough to be safe for pedestrian travel over it as well as for vehicular traffic to pass safely over it at a legal rate of speed. The permittee shall maintain temporary paving for a period not exceeding thirty days after all backfilling is completed, unless additional time is required by the administrative authority and shall keep the same safe for pedestrian and vehicular traffic until the excavation has been resurfaced with permanent paving; except, that if it is impractical to maintain the surface of the temporary paving in a safe condition for pedestrian travel or vehicular traffic, then the permittee shall maintain barriers and lights as required by this chapter. 
(Prior code § 34-45; Ord. 844 § 22, 1985) 
12.24.340 - Permission required-Work specifications. 
    The city reserves the right to restore pavements in all cases. No permittee under this chapter shall make any permanent or temporary restoration, partial or complete, unless specific permission has been given by the administrative authority. Permission to restore concrete pavement or sheet asphalt surface will not be granted except under unusual conditions. The following provisions shall be followed in surface restoration: 
A.  Base material and subgrade shall be restored to that existing prior to the excavation or in accordance with standards for construction of new streets used by the city as determined by the administrative authority. 
B.  Portland cement concrete used in the repair of trenches shall not have a slump in excess of two inches. 
C.  Portland cement concrete used in the repair of trenches in streets shall be replaced with a thickness equivalent to that removed, but in no case less than five inches. Bituminous pavement shall be replaced at a thickness as one inch greater than the existing pavement, but in no case less than two inches. 
D.  Portland cement sidewalks shall be replaced with the thickness of that removed but in no case shall the thickness be less than three and one-half inches and such sidewalk shall be of a color and texture of the adjoining sidewalk. 
E.  Expansion joints in Portland cement patches shall be matched with saw cut lines. 
F.  Portland cement shall be finished to match the texture of that of the adjoining pavement. 
G.  Concrete shall be compacted by tamping, rodding or mechanical vibration. 
H.  Repairs in rock and oil streets shall be made in accordance with the existing specifications for bituminous type pavement. 
I.  Seal coats may be required by the administrative authority when the street has been seal coated or when, in the opinion of the administrative authority, the quality of the restored surface requires seal coating. 
(Prior code § 34-46; Ord. 844 §§ 23 - 25, 1985) 
12.24.350 - Security deposit-Generally. 
    The applicant shall make a deposit equal to the estimated charge for restoration and inspection at schedule prices; unless: 
A.  The applicant opens a running account with the city by making an initial deposit suitable to the city, to be replenished by the applicant voluntarily or upon request by the city. No permit shall be issued under this provision unless there is an unencumbered amount in the applicant's account sufficient to cover the estimated restoration and inspection charge on the permit applied for; 
B.  The applicant operates under a city contract involving the opening of public ways, in which case he may obtain a street opening permit without cash deposit; 
C.  The applicant is an appropriate city or county department whose functions require the installation or maintenance of underground structures; 
D.  The applicant is a corporation whose franchise or provisions of this chapter empower it to make its own paving restoration, but such permits shall be issued only when the restoration work keeps fully apace with the openings being made. Such corporations shall pay promptly all bills for restoration done by the city or its contractor. 
(Prior code § 34-47 (part); Ord. 844 § 26, 1985) 
12.24.360 - Security deposit-When additional sum required. 
    If at any time during the course of an excavation it appears that the cash on deposit under this article is inadequate to cover the cost of restoration and inspection, an additional sum shall be deposited by the permittee in an amount equal to the difference between the deposit and the revised estimate of charge. 
(Prior code § 34-47 (part); Ord. 844 § 27, 1985) 
12.24.370 - Security deposit-Disposition and determination. 
    Any special payment or general deposit made under this article shall serve as payment for the cost of surface restoration and inspection. Each deposit shall be based on the schedule of prices provided by the administrative authority and shall be adequate to cover permanent restoration. The city shall use any or all of any such deposit to restore the public place in as good condition as it was prior to the excavation. In the event that the entire amount of the deposit is not used for the restoration, the remainder will be refunded to the permittee. 
(Prior code § 34-47 (part); Ord. 844 § 28, 1985) 
12.24.380 - Inspection-Permittee liable for cost. 
    Where a contractor makes his own surface restoration after an excavation or the operation is of unusual size or difficulty, the city reserves the right to assign an inspector to control street opening or street restoration. In such cases, the permittee under this chapter shall bear the entire cost of such inspection and shall deposit with the city the estimated cost of such inspection in advance. If the cost is underestimated, the permittee shall advance additional funds. 
(Prior code § 34-48 (part)) 
12.24.390 - Settlement-Liability period. 
    If any settlement in a restored area occurs within a period of twenty-four months from the completion of the excavating work, it shall be considered as conclusive evidence of defective backfilling. Any expense incurred by the city in correcting such settlement shall be paid by the permittee. Acceptance or approval of any excavation work by the administrative authority shall not prevent the city from asserting any claims against the permittee. .The administrative authority's presence during the performance of any excavation work shall not relieve the permittee of his responsibilities under this chapter. 
(Prior code § 34-48 (part)) 
12.24.400 - Settlement-Acceptance of liability. 
    A permittee under this chapter, in accepting and acting under an excavation permit, thereby agrees to assume full responsibility for injury or damage to persons or property incurred because of any settlement of a restored area and further agrees to pay all costs involved in reconditioning such areas. 
(Prior code § 34-49) 
Article VII. - Cleanup 

12.24.410 - Removal of debris from streets. 
    As excavation work progresses, all streets shall be thoroughly cleaned of all rubbish, excess earth, rock and other debris resulting from such work. All cleanup operations at the location of such excavation shall be accomplished at the expense of the permittee and shall be completed to the satisfaction of the administrative authority and immediately after completion of such work the permittee shall, at his own expense, clean up and remove all refuse and unused materials of any kind resulting from such work and upon failure to do so within twenty-four hours after having been notified to do so by the administrative authority, such work may be done by the administrative authority and the cost thereof charged to the permittee and the permittee and their surety shall be liable for the cost thereof. 
(Prior code § 34-47; Ord. 844 § 29, 1985) 
12.24.420 - Gutters to remain unobstructed. 
    A permittee under this chapter shall maintain all gutters free and unobstructed for the full depth of the adjacent curb and for at least one foot in width from the face of such curb at the gutter line. Whenever a gutter crosses an intersecting street, an adequate waterway shall be provided and at all times maintained. 
(Prior code § 34-38) 
12.24.430 - Disposal of runoff. 
    A permittee under this chapter shall make provisions to dispose of all surplus water, muck, silt, slickings or other runoff pumped from excavations or resulting from sluicing or other operations and shall be responsible for any damage resulting from its failure to so provide. 
(Prior code § 34-39) 
Chapter 12.28 - SUBSTRUCTURES 
Sections: 

12.28.010 - Interested persons to file maps. 
    Every person owning, using, controlling or having an interest in substructures, under the surface of any public place used for the purpose of supplying or conveying gas, electricity, communication impulse, water, steam, ammonia or oil in the city, shall file with the city engineer or his authorized representative a set of maps, each drawn to a scale of not less than one inch to two hundred feet, showing in detail the location, size, description and date of installation, if known, of all substructures, except a service line designed to serve a single property owner, beneath the surface of the public place belonging to, used by or under the control of such person having any interest and shall file with the city engineer or his authorized representative, within fifteen days after January 1 of each year, a corrected set of maps, each drawn to scale, including all installations made during the previous year to and including the last day of such year; provided, that a public utility owner may, at its option, provide corrected atlas sheets at more frequent intervals. 
(Prior code § 34-16) 
12.28.020 - Abandonment-Report-When removal required. 
    Whenever the use of a substructure is abandoned, except the abandonment of a service line designed to serve a single property owner, the person owning, using, controlling or having an interest therein shall, within thirty days after such abandonment, file with the city engineer or his authorized representative a statement in writing giving in detail the location of the substructure so abandoned. If such abandoned substructure is in the way or subsequently becomes in the way of an installation of the city or any other public body, which installation is pursuant to a governmental function, the owner shall remove such abandoned substructure or pay the cost of its removal during the course of excavation for construction of the facility by the city or any other public body. 
(Prior code § 34-17) 
12.28.030 - Minimum depths. 
    No person shall, without written permission of the administrative authority, install any substructure, except manholes, vaults, valve castings, culverts and catch basins, at a depth less than twenty-four inches; provided, that the administrative authority may permit a lesser depth in special cases. 
(Prior code § 34-40 (part); Ord. 844 § 30, 1985) 
12.28.040 - Applicability when grade uneven. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall impose a duty upon the permittee to maintain such specifications as required in this chapter upon subsequent changes of grade in the surface, unless the grade in the substructure interferes with the maintenance of or travel on a public street. 
(Prior code § 34-40 (part)) 
Chapter 12.32 - SIDEWALKS AND CURBS 
Sections: 

12.32.010 - City manager's order-Adjoining land owner's responsibility. 
    All owners of land adjoining any street, road alley or other public way in the city shall construct, reconstruct or repair sidewalks and curbs along such street, road, alley or other public way adjoining to such land when ordered to do so by the city manager. 
(Prior code § 34-56) 
12.32.020 - City manager's order-Form and contents. 
    When the city manager issues any order to any property owner to construct, reconstruct o repair sidewalks or curbs, the order shall be in writing and shall designate the location, manner of construction, construction material, width and grade of such sidewalk or curb to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired; provided that the specifications of the city manager shall not be such as to require any property owner to construct a sidewalk or curb of different material or in a different manner than is required of the owners of other land in the same block fronting the same street, road, alley o other public way. 
(Prior code § 34-57) 
12.32.030 - City manager's order-Determination criteria. 
    It shall be the duty of the city manager to order the construction, reconstruction or repair of sidewalks and curbs when in so doing safe, and satisfactory walkways will be provided for children enroute to or from school or when because of existing conditions in any area of the city the public safety, convenience and general welfare will be served by the construction, reconstruction or repair of such sidewalks and curbs. 
(Prior code § 34-58) 
12.32.040 - City manager's order-Service. 
    The written order of the city manager provided for in Section 12.32.020 shall be served personally upon the property owner, if he is to be found within the city, by the chief of police or some member of the police force designated by the chief of police to make such service. Service shall be by registered or certified mail if the owner lives outside the city and his address is known; otherwise, such order shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation published in the city. 
(Prior code § 34-59) 
12.32.050 - City manager's order-Commencement of work after service. 
    When an order has been served, mailed or published, as provided for in Section 12.32.040, the owner shall, within two weeks after such service, mailing or publication, commence the construction, reconstruction or repair of such sidewalk or curb and finish same without delay. 
(Prior code § 34-60) 
12.32.060 - When work done by city-Collection of costs. 
    In the event an owner fails to proceed as provided in Section 12.32.050, the city manager shall proceed without delay to cause the sidewalk or curb to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired, paying for the cost thereof out of available funds of the city authorized by law, and shall immediately assess and levy the cost thereof against the lot or parcel of land upon which such sidewalk or curb fronts, certify same to the county treasurer, where it shall be collected in the manner provided for the collection of city taxes, and shall, upon becoming delinquent, be subjected to the same interest, penalty and liens as other delinquent city, county or state taxes. 
(Prior code § 34-61) 
12.32.070 - Disposition of collected costs. 
    All money collected and returned to the city under the provisions of Section 12.32.060 shall be credited to the fund from which payment for the construction, reconstruction or repair of sidewalks or curbs was made. 
(Prior code § 34-62) 
Chapter 12.36 - DRIVEWAYS 
Sections: 

12.36.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
A.  "Change of use" means any change or purpose for which any land, building or structure is occupied, maintained, arranged, designed or intended. 
B.  "Driveway" means any area, construction or facility between the roadway of a street and private property to provide access for vehicles from the roadway of a street to private property. 
C.  "Parking strip" means the space between the street, roadway or curbline and the property line, with the exception of the sidewalk area. 
D.  "Roadway" means the paved, improved or proper driving portion of a street, designed and ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
E.  "Sidewalk area" means that portion of the space lying between the street roadway or curbline and the property line which is reserved for sidewalks, either existing or proposed. 
F.  "Street" means any street, alley or other public place within the city. 
(Prior code 34-63) 
12.36.020 - Compliance with chapter. 
    Any access from a public roadway to private property hereafter provided, constructed, altered or repaired shall be through driveways constructed according to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 34-64) 
12.36.030 - Permit-Required. 
    Except when included in a building permit, no person shall commence work on the construction, alteration, repair or removal of any driveway or the paving of any parking strip on any street, alley or other public place in the city without a written permit first having been obtained from the city engineer. 
(Prior code § 34-65) 
12.36.040 - Permit-Application. 
A.  Any party requesting a permit required by Section 12.36.030 shall file a written application therefor with the city engineer. Such application shall be made on a standard city form provided for that purpose, and shall include: 
1.  The name and address of the applicant; 
2.  The name and address of the owner of the property abutting the street where the work is proposed; 
3.  The exact location of the proposed work, giving the street address or legal description of the property involved; 
4.  A detailed plan showing the exact dimensions of the abutting property and the exact dimensions and location of all existing or proposed driveways and other pertinent features within the limits of the frontage of such property; 
5.  The location of buildings, loading platforms or off-street parking facilities being served or to be served by such driveways. 
B.  The city engineer may require, at his discretion, the filing of any other information when, in his opinion, such information is necessary to properly enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 34-66) 
12.36.050 - Plans must comply with other regulations. 
    No plan shall be approved nor a permit under this chapter issued where it appears that the proposed work or any part thereof conflicts with the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city; nor shall issuance of a permit under this chapter be construed as a waiver of the provisions of the zoning regulations or other ordinance requirements concerning the plan. 
(Prior code § 34-67) 
12.36.060 - Plans must comply with city standards. 
    All construction outlined in this chapter shall be performed in accordance with the city's standard plans and specifications, available and on file in the office of the city engineer, and shall be performed to the satisfaction of the city engineer or his duly authorized representatives. 
(Prior code § 34-68) 
12.36.070 - Specifications-Location. 
A.  No driveway shall be located so as to create a hazard to pedestrians or motorists or invite or compel illegal or unsafe traffic movements. 
B.  Unless otherwise approved by the city engineer, all driveways including the returns, shall be constructed within lines at right angles to the curbline and passing through the front property corners. 
C.  No driveway shall be constructed in such manner as to create a hazard to any existing street lighting standard, utility pole, traffic regulating device or fire hydrant. The cost of relocating any such street structure, when necessary to do so, shall be borne by the abutting property owner. Relocation of any street structure shall be performed only by or through the person holding authority for the particular structure involved. 
D.  No construction, alteration or repair shall be permitted for any driveway which can be used only as a parking space or which provides access only to the area between the street roadway and private property. 
(Prior code § 34-69 (a)) 
12.36.080 - Specifications-Dimensions-Exceptions. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the width of any driveway shall not exceed thirty-five feet, exclusive of the radii of the returns, the measurement being made parallel to the centerline of the street roadway. Where driveways are to enter on courts or alleys having a right-of-way width of forty feet or less, the width of the driveways may exceed thirty-five feet, and the limitation of the percentage of property frontage in driveways may be waived; provided, that the overall plan of the location of such driveways shall meet the approval of the city engineer. 
B.  The width of any driveway shall not be less than ten feet, exclusive of the radii of the returns, the measurement being made at right angles to the centerline of the driveway. 
C.  1.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection A., the total width of all driveways for any one ownership on a street shall not exceed fifty percent of the frontage of that ownership along the street. Any driveway which has become abandoned or unused through a change of the conditions for which it was originally intended or which for any other reason has become unnecessary may be closed and the owner required to replace any such driveway with a standard curb and sidewalk under the provisions of Chapter 12.32. 
2.  Whenever in a single ownership the total width of existing driveways on a street is over fifty percent of the frontage of the ownership of that street, such existing driveways shall be made to conform to the provisions of this article in the event of any of the following changes: 
a.  Any alteration or repair of such existing driveways in excess of twenty-five percent of the frontage of the ownership on that street or any widening of any such existing driveways; 
b.  Any construction of additional driveways in the ownership or the alteration or repair of any driveways in the ownership in excess of twenty-five percent of the frontage on which the driveways are to be altered or repaired, when the ownership has frontage on two or more streets; 
c.  any change of use of the ownership. 
3.  Upon the alteration or repair of any one or more of the driveways as aforesaid, the city manager may require such changes in any or all of the driveways of that ownership necessitated for better movement of traffic or to provide better protection to pedestrians. 
4.  Where a single ownership is developed into more than one unit of operation each sufficient in itself to meet the requirements of off-street parking or loading, as may be required by the zoning regulations, and where the safety of pedestrians or vehicular traffic is not endangered, then the requirements outlined above may be construed to apply to each separate unit of operation rather than to the entire ownership. 
D.  There shall be not more than two driveways on one street for any one ownership except where a single ownership is developed into more than one unit of operation each sufficient in itself to meet the requirements of off-street parking or loading, as may be required by the zoning regulations, and where the necessity for separate access to the street is evident. In such cases, there shall be not more than two driveways on one street for-any one unit of operation. 
E.  The radius for any driveway return shall be five feet, unless otherwise directed by the city engineer. 
F.  The angle between any driveway and the street roadway or curbline shall not be less than forty-five degrees. 
(Prior code § 34-69(b)(part)) 
12.36.090 - Specifications-Waiver of requirements. 
    In the event the city council should determine that, in the application of the provisions of Sections 12.36.070 and 12.36.080 to the use of any property, there is created an undue hardship, the city council may, through action in regular meeting, grant an exception to the property owner insofar as complying with the provisions of Sections 12.36.070 and 12.36.080 is concerned. 
(Prior code § 34-70) 
Chapter 12.40 - PUBLIC WAYS 
Sections: 

12.40.010 - Opening-Authority. 
    The city council may, by resolution or otherwise, provide for the opening of any street or any part thereof or for the creation of any new street or alley or for the grading or otherwise improving any street or alley within the city. 
(Prior code § 34-53) 
12.40.020 - Bridges-Improving or building contracts. 
    The city council may, by resolution or otherwise, provide for the making of any contract for the building of bridges or improving the same and repairing approaches thereto. 
(Prior code § 34-54) 
12.40.030 - Bidding. 
    Before any work is done or contract made for any work authorized by this title, an estimate of the cost thereof shall be made by the city engineer and an advertisement for bids shall be made, published and accepted as provided by state law. 
(Prior code § 34-55) 
Division III. - Parks 
Chapter 12.44 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

12.44.010 - Areas designated. 
    To the fullest and most complete extent legally permissible and not heretofore assured and accomplished and subject to conditions and covenants heretofore of record and subject to present uses of the property hereinafter described and the continuance of the same without extension, the city confirms, formally bestows and recognizes the names of, dedicates and devotes to and reserves and sets aside in trust for public park, recreational, playground, pleasure, educational, historical and amusement purposes, the following public parks and preserves within the city: 
A.  Undine Park, bounded by Park Avenue, Ord Street, Fifth Street and Seventh Street; 
B.  Washington Park, bounded by Rainbow Avenue, Sheridan Street, Eighteenth Street and Twenty-first Street; 
C.  LaBonte Park, bounded by Shield Street, Canby Street, Fourth Street and Ninth Street, but subject to the continuation of the city's garage, storage and workshop facilities within the one-half block abutting upon Fourth Street; which shall not be expanded east of the alley between Fourth Street and Fifth Street projected north and south through such park; 
D.  LaPrele Park, comprising and containing the lands conveyed to the city for park and recreation purposes by Union Realty Company in a deed dated April 30, 1929, recorded at page 283 of Book "U" of Deeds in the county clerk's office on June 14, 1929, lying east of Corthell Road, north of Spring Creek Addition, south of Twin Parks, Twin Parks Second and Spring Creek Second Additions, and along the course of Spring Creek and the city's flood control channel in the north one-half of Section Three, Township Fifteen North, Range Seventy-three West of the sixth P.M.; 
E.  All of Block Fourteen. in the University Place Addition, bounded by Gibbon Street, Harney Street, Thirteenth Street and Fourteenth Street; 
F.  Spring Creek Park, a tract of land in Sections 3 and 4, Township 15 north, Range 73 west of 6th P.M., 80 feet wide known as the City of Laramie "STORM AND FLOOD WATERS CHANNEL" lying 48' northerly and 32' southerly of the following described line: Beginning at a point that lies S4° - 57' W92.2 feet from the southwest corner of Block 5, Overland Addition to the City of Laramie, thence S85° - 00' E 167.3 feet to point of curvature; thence northwesterly 262.7 feet on a 20° curve to the left to point of tangency; thence N42° - 28'E 316.3 feet to point of curvature; thence northeasterly 133.3 feet on a 20° curve to the right to point of tangency; thence N69° - 07' E 1013.9 feet to point of curvature; thence northeasterly 100.0 feet on a 13° curve to the left to point of tangency; thence N56° - 07' E 378.8 feet to point of curvature; thence easterly 170.1 feet on a 20° curve to the right to point of tangency; thence S89° - 47' E 2579.1 feet to point of curvature; hence easterly 187.4 feet on a 9° curve to the left to point of reverse curvature; thence easterly 99.2 feet on a 17° curve to the right to point of tangency; thence S89° - 47'E 224.8 feet to a point; thence N89° - 49'E 697.6 feet to a point; thence N78° - 42'E 953.1 to the centerline of Corthell Road. 
G.  LaRamie Park, described as two tracts of land in the NE 1/4 of Section 34, T. 16 N., R. 73 W., 6th P.M., Albany County, Wyoming, more particularly described as follows: 
Tract A 
    Beginning at a point which bears S40°46'02?E, 773.92 feet from the north 1/4 corner of said Section 34, said point lying on a curve concave northwesterly having a radius of 610.00 feet and a central angle of 46°57'46?; thence 154.30 feet along said curve in a northeasterly direction (chord bearing N49°21'21?E, 153.89 feet) to a point of tangency; thence N42°06'33?E, 390.00 feet to a point of curvature on a curve concave southerly having a radius of 465.00 feet and a central angle of 47°34'54?; thence 386.16 feet along said curve in a northeasterly direction (chord bearing N65°54'00?E, 375.16 feet) to a point of tangency; thence N89°41'27?E, 80.00 feet to a point; thence S00°15'17?E, 1230.54 feet to a point on a curve concave southeasterly on the north right-of-way line of Armory Road, said curve having a radius of 590.00 feet and a central angle of 31°24'19?; thence 224.93 feet along said curve in a southwesterly direction (chord bearing S72°20'06?W, 223.58 feet) to a point on the curve; thence N38°08'54?W, 960.29 feet to the point of beginning; said tract containing 15.11 acres more or less. Bearings are referenced to the north line of said Section 34 as being N89°41'27?E. 
Tract B

(Prior code § 27-1; Ord. 1076 § 1, 1992; Ord. 1328 § 1, 2000) 
12.44.020 - Acceptance of gifts-Generally. 
    The city council may receive and accept donations, contributions, bequests, devises or gifts of any kind of labor, services, money, buildings, equipment or other property of any kind, intended and designed to further the proper objectives and use of any and all parks and the city irrevocably binds itself to observe, respect and carry out the conditions, intent and restrictions with which any such gift may be made and accepted by the city, agrees that any donation so accepted by the city shall constitute a binding and irrevocable contract and agrees and covenants with each donor that the foregoing parks shall be maintained as such and all such gifts shall be preserved and enjoyed inviolate. The city shall provide suitable plaques, signs or other appropriate designation of the donor or developer of any particular function, equipment or area in any such park. 
(Prior code § 27-2) 
12.44.030 - Acceptance of gifts-Future development. 
    Upon the same basis and terms as are set forth in Section 12.44.020, the city may at any time and from time to time receive, accept, develop and make available for public use any similar park areas, for any or all public purposes provided in this division, which may at any time hereafter be given, leased, devised or otherwise made available to the city, either within or outside of the present corporate limits of the city. 
(Prior code § 27-3) 
Chapter 12.48 - ORGANIZED ACTIVITY PERMITS 
Sections: 

12.48.010 - Closed areas. 
    Any section or part of any park may be declared closed to the public by the director of the city parks and recreation or designee at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals (daily or otherwise) and either entirely or merely to certain uses, as the director of the city parks and recreation or designee finds reasonably necessary. 
(Prior code § 27-4(a); Ord. 627 § 1 (part), 1980; Ord. 710 § 1 (part), 1982; Ord. 1512 § 5, 2007) 
12.48.020 - Generally-Facilities use park permit. 
A.  Any group which desires to use parks and related facilities for organized activities may make application to the director of the city parks and recreation or designee for a facilities use park permit. Any individual or group of any size desiring to consume alcoholic beverages shall in addition to the application for a facilities use park permit make application to the city manager or designee for an open container permit in accordance with the procedures outlined in Chapter 12.60. Any individual or group of any size desiring to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages shall in addition to the application for a facilities use park permit make application to the city manager or designee for a catering or malt beverage permit special events in accordance with the procedures for a special event permit as outlined in Chapter 12.60. 
B.  The city manager or designee may issue, place conditions on an open container permit or a malt beverage permit or catering permit for special events or deny an open container permit or malt beverage or catering permit for special events as outlined in Chapter 12.60. The city manager or designee shall act upon the application for an open container permit or a malt beverage or catering permit for special events within five days after the filing thereof. If the city manager or designee disapproves the application for failure to meet the conditions as outlined in Section 12.60.060 and the requirements of the section herein, the city manager or designee shall state the reason for the denial or stipulate additional conditions. The applicant shall have the right to appeal to city council the denial of an open container permit or a malt beverage or catering permit for special events or conditions of an open container permit or a malt or catering permit for special events. A notice of appeal shall be filed with the city manager's office setting forth the grounds for the appeal within three business days after receipt or personal delivery of a notice of denial or permit condition(s). The city council shall review the appeal prior to the requested date of an open container permit or a malt beverage or catering permit for special events either at the next scheduled meeting of city council or at a special meeting to review the appeal. The city council's decision shall be final and not subject to further appeal. 
(Prior code § 27-4(b) (part); Ord. 627 § 1 (part), 1980; Ord. 710 § 1 (part), 1982; Ord. 1512 § 6, 2007; Ord. No. 1730 , § 1, 5-16-2017) 
12.48.030 - Application for facility use park permit. 
A.  A person seeking issuance of a facility use park permit under this chapter shall file an application with the director of the city parks and recreation or designee. 
B.  The application shall contain the following information: 
1.  The name and address of the applicant; 
2.  The name and address of the person, persons, corporation or association sponsoring the activity, if any; 
3.  The day and hours for which the permit is desired; 
4.  The park or portion thereof for which such permit is desired; 
5.  An estimate of the anticipated number of persons attending; 
6.  Whether or not the applicant wishes to consume alcoholic beverages or dispense alcoholic beverages during the time specified in the permit application and in the area specified in such application and if so, proof of application and issuance of an open container permit or malt beverage or catering permit for special events by city manager or designee or city council; 
7.  Any other information which the director of the city parks and recreation or designee finds reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a facility use park permit should be issued under this chapter. 
(Prior code § 27-4(b)(1); Ord. 627 § 1 (part), 1980; Ord. 710 § 1 (part), 1982; Ord. 1512 § 7, 2007) 
12.48.040 - Issuance standards for facility use park permit. 
    The director of the city parks and recreation or designee shall issue a facility use park permit hereunder when he finds: 
A.  That the proposed activity or use, including the location in the park for the proposed consumption of alcoholic beverages, will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the reasonable enjoyment of the general public of the park; 
B.  That the proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation; 
C.  That the proposed activity or use is not reasonably anticipated to incite violence, crime or disorderly conductor any other violations of city code; 
D.  That the proposed activity will not entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city; 
E.  That the facilities desired have not been reserved for other use at the day and hour stated in the application; 
F.  That the proposed activity is consistent with the public park, recreational, playground, pleasure, educational, historical and amusement purposes for which parks are dedicated. 
(Prior code § 27-4(b)(2); Ord. 627 § 1 (part), 1980; Ord. 710 § 1 (part), 1982; Ord. 1118 § 1, 1993; Ord. 1512 § 8, 2007) 
12.48.050 - Facility use park permit-Fees-Damage deposit. 
A.  The director of the city parks and recreation or designee shall collect a park use fee from any person or group wishing to reserve city park facilities. Park use fees are applicable to each individual park facility as designated by the parks and recreation master fee schedule. 
B.  Reserved. 
C.  Reserved. 
D.  Reserved. 
E.  The director of the city parks and recreation or designee may collect damage deposits as designated by the parks and recreation master fee schedule. 
1.  The director of the city parks and recreation or designee may waive the damage deposit requirement upon an assessment of the risk of damage and approval by the city manager or designee. 
(Prior code § 27-4(b)(3)(part); Ord. 627 § 1 (part), 1980; Ord. 710 § 1 (part), 1982; Ord. 822 § 1, 1984; Ord. 1106 § 1, 1993; Ord. 1118 § 2, 1993; Ord. 1157 § 1, 1995; Ord. 1261 § 1, 1999; Ord. 1429 § 1, 2004; Ord. 1512 § 10, 2007; Ord. No. 1591, § 1, 12-21-2010; Ord. No. 1643, § 1, 5-7-2013; Ord. No. 1730 , §§ 2-6, 5-16-2017) 
Note- Ord. 1512 contained two sections numbered 10. 
12.48.070 - Damage deposit-Refund-Inspection. 
    Once the event has concluded, the director of the city parks and recreation or designee shall cause an inspection to be made of the area used, and shall determine the extent of any damage to park property, or litter, and the amount of any costs or charges that are incurred as a result of such use and shall thereafter and forthwith assess and/or retain that portion of the deposit necessary to restore the damaged property and return the balance, if any, of the deposit to the person from whom it was acquired. Nothing in this section shall relieve the permittee of facility use park permit from the liability imposed by Section 12.48.100 and any amounts withheld by the director of the city parks and recreation or designee pursuant to this section shall be held as an offset against the total liability of the permittee holding the facility use park permit. 
(Ord. 1512 § 10, 2007: Ord. 710 § 1 (part), 1982: Ord. 627 § 1 (part), 1980: prior code § 27-4(b)(3)(part); Ord. No. 1730 , § 7, 5-16-2017) 
Note- Ord. 1512 contained two sections numbered 10. 
12.48.080 - Refusal of facility use park permit-Appeal. 
    Within fifteen days after receipt of an application, the director of the city parks and recreation or designee shall issue the facility use park permit or shall apprise the applicant in writing of his reasons for denying a facility use park permit, and any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal in writing to the city manager or designee, within fifteen days after the date of such refusal, who shall consider the application under the standards set forth in Section 12.48.040 and sustain or overrule the director of the city parks and recreation or designee decision within fifteen days after receipt of the notice of appeal. The decision of the city manager or designee shall be final. 
(Prior code § 27-4(b)(4); Ord. 627 § 1 (part), 1980; Ord. 710 § 1 (part), 1982; Ord. 1512 § 11, 2007) 
12.48.085 - Previously issued facility use park permit and open container permit-Public park. 
    Any permit issued for the use of a facility in a public park prior to March 30, 2007 or the effective date of the amendment of this chapter, whichever is earlier, shall be valid.
