(Prior code § 32-19) 
13.32.030 - Internal maintenance. 
    The inside of every sewer service line connecting with the sewer utility shall be left smooth and perfectly clean throughout its entire length and the ends of all lines not to be immediately used shall be securely guarded against the introduction of earth, sand or other foreign material by bricks and cement or other watertight and impervious material. 
(Prior code § 32-20) 
13.32.040 - Cost-Responsibility of property owner. 
    The cost of installing the sewer service line shall be paid by the property owner. The owners of the property served by a sewer service line shall be responsible for repairing or replacing such sewer service line when, in the opinion of the city engineer, such line has become inoperative due to stoppages, crushing, settlement or any other defect. 
(Prior code § 32-21) 
13.32.050 - Mains-Minimum size. 
    The minimum size of sewer mains constructed as a part of the city sewer utility shall be eight inches in diameter. 
(Prior code § 32-22) 
13.32.060 - Mains-City's share of cost. 
A.  Except in such instances where a single sewer district, subdivision or development under one ownership requires a main greater than eight inches in diameter, the city shall participate in the cost of installing larger sized mains. The extent of city participation shall be based on the following percentages of the total cost of sewers greater than eight inches in diameter: 
1.  For ten-inch mains, the percentage of the city's participation shall be fifteen percent; 
2.  For twelve-inch mains, the percentage of the city's participation shall be twenty-five percent; 
3.  For fifteen-inch mains, the percentage of the city's participation shall be thirty-five percent; 
4.  For eighteen-inch mains, the percentage of the city's participation shall be forty-five percent; 
5.  For mains larger than eighteen inches in diameter, the extent of city participation shall be determined by the city council. 
B.  In those instances where a district, subdivision or development under one ownership is of such size that mains larger than eight inches in diameter are required, the entire cost of such oversize mains shall be paid by the district or subdivider. 
(Prior code § 32-23) 
13.32.070 - Subdivisions-Main extension contract. 
    No sewer shall be constructed in a platted subdivision approved after April 17, 1962, until the subdivider and the city have executed a sewer main extension contract. 
(Prior code § 32-24) 
13.32.080 - Subdivisions-Installation by subdivider-Exception. 
    The subdivider shall install the mains in his subdivision by contract upon approval of the plans and specifications by the city, execution of sewer extension contract and city inspection of actual construction; provided, that the city may elect to install the mains, in which case the subdivider shall deposit with the city the estimated cost of the sewer construction, plus engineering and administrative costs. The city shall then proceed to construct the sewer under contract. If at any time the actual cost exceeds the amount deposited, the subdivider shall immediately deposit sufficient funds to complete the work. 
(Prior code § 32-25) 
13.32.090 - Subdivisions-Subdivider to pay costs. 
    The subdivider shall pay the costs of construction of all sewer mains and appurtenances to, in and through his subdivision, except as otherwise provided in this division. Sewer mains shall always be extended to the farthest point or points upgrade in a platted subdivision so that the system may be perpetuated. 
(Prior code § 32-26) 
13.32.100 - Subdivisions-Undeveloped areas. 
    When a subdivider finds it necessary to construct a sewer through undeveloped areas to serve his platted subdivision, the entire cost of such sewer line shall be paid by the subdivider unless the oversize main provisions of Section 13.32.060 are applicable. At the time of annexation or as the property abutting such sewer is developed and connections are made to the sewer, the city may collect a charge per front foot based upon the original construction cost and if so collected shall reimburse the original subdivider to the extent of the collections so made; provided, that in no event shall such reimbursement exceed the total cost of the sewer. A subdivider's right to reimbursement under the provisions of this section shall terminate fifteen years after execution of the sewer extension contract. 
(Prior code § 32-27) 
13.32.110 - Extension to city property not part of subdivision-Special assessment. 
    Extension of sewers to serve property within the city, but not a part of a subdivision platted after April 17, 1962, shall be financed by special assessment against the benefitted property or under such terms and conditions as the city council provides by resolution. 
(Prior code § 32-28) 
13.32.120 - Pumping stations-Liability for costs. 
    When pumping stations are required, the cost of constructing such stations shall be the responsibility of the property served thereby. In those instances where it appears that more than one platted subdivision may be served by the pump station, the city may require a larger capacity than that necessary to serve the initial development. Where such larger capacity is required the additional cost may be paid by the sewer utility and thereafter collected from other property owners or subdividers connecting to lines served by the pump station. Such charges shall be paid prior to the time any connections are made. 
(Prior code § 32-29) 
13.32.130 - Force mains serving areas otherwise unable to enter sewer utility. 
    Force mains required to serve an area not otherwise able to enter the city's sewerage system shall be constructed at the expense of the owners of the property to be served thereby. 
(Prior code § 32-30) 
13.32.140 - Gravity systems-When required. 
    In those instances where pumping stations and force mains are required, the sewerage system shall be designed so as to permit an eventual connection into a gravity system with a minimum of expense. Where practicable, easements shall be provided and lines constructed to tie into the gravity system. The city may require deposits, where deemed necessary, from the property owners requiring such force system to insure the eventual construction of gravity lines. 
(Prior code § 32-31) 
13.32.150 - Private sewer connections not to affect assessability of property. 
    The existence of private sewers connected with the city sewer utility shall not affect the assessability of property for sewers constructed according to city specifications. 
(Prior code § 32-32) 
Chapter 13.36 - EXTENSIONS 
Sections: 

13.36.010 - Authority to enter into agreement. 
    The city council may in its sole discretion enter into agreements with customers whose lands lie outside the corporate limits, to extend the city's sewer system for the use, needs and requirements of such customers. 
(Prior code § 32-41) 
13.36.020 - Prerequisite findings. 
    Before the city council enters into any extension agreement, it shall find: 
A.  That the extension of sewer service is economically feasible; 
B.  That the property to be served is readily adaptable to and can be made to conform, within a reasonable time to be fixed by the city council, to the then existing ordinances of the city which relate to subdivision, platting, zoning and construction of improvements; 
C.  That the property to be served is not currently contiguous to the city limits and cannot therefore be annexed to the city pursuant to the laws of the state, but that such property can reasonably be expected to be annexable to the city within the foreseeable future; 
D.  That such extension would help promote the orderly growth and development of the city; 
E.  That such extension would help promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city; 
F.  That such extension would help promote ecological and esthetic considerations in the growth and development of the city; 
G.  That such extension is generally in the best interests of the citizens of the city. 
(Prior code § 32-42) 
13.36.030 - Service charges-Rate determination. 
    The ratio of the rate charged to the customer to the then current established rate within the corporate limits, shall remain constant as to all agreements relating to the extension of service beyond the corporate limits. 
(Prior code § 32-43) 
13.36.040 - Service charges-Application. 
    Subject to the provisions of Section 13.36.030, the rates charged shall be uniformly applied and shall not exceed two times the then current established rate being charged within the corporate limits. 
(Prior code § 32-44) 
Division III. - Utility bills 
Chapter 13.40 - ACCOUNTS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

13.40.010 - Establishment-Purpose. 
A.  It shall be the duty of the city manager to establish accounts for the purpose of billing and collecting charges and fees specified under Section 8.16.170 through 8.16.230, 8.52.010, 13.16.010, 13.44.010 through 13.44.040, 13.48.010 through 13.48.050 and 13.52.010. Such accounts shall be used for the billing and collection of any other charges occasional in frequency, provided for by ordinance and related in nature to the above fees and charges. 
(Prior code § 12-12(a); Ord. 891 § 1, 1987; Ord. No. 1724 , § 1, 12-20-2016) 
13.40.020 - Establishment-For each property. 
    An account shall be established for each parcel of property, abode, business or address to which any or all of the charges referred to in Section 13.40.010 apply; provided, that additional accounts shall be established for locations or addresses having more than one water meter. All accounts under this chapter shall be carried in the names of the property owner, agent, tenant, purchaser or lessee of each such parcel of property, abode, business or address. 
(Prior code § 12-12(b)) 
13.40.030 - Billing frequency. 
    No less frequently than once each quarter nor more frequently than once each month, a statement of each account, shall be prepared and sent to the name and mailing address appearing on each account; provided, that any property owner, agent, tenant, purchaser or lessee in whose name there is an account may request in writing that the statement be addressed to a banking institution; provided further, that nothing in this chapter shall prevent all accounts from being divided into groups with different billing dates for the purpose of establishing convenient billing cycles. 
(Prior code § 12-12(c)) 
13.40.040 - Prorating statements. 
    Statements for periods less than one quarter including charges or fees which are expressed as quarterly charges or fees shall be appropriately prorated to reflect the actual period of time for which services were received. 
(Prior code § 12-12(d)) 
13.40.050 - Payment period-Delinquency. 
    Statements shall be due and payable at the office of the city treasurer immediately upon receipt of the statement, and shall be delinquent if not paid before the expiration of one month and ten days after the date the statement was prepared for mailing. 
(Prior code § 12-12(e)) 
13.40.060 - Payment-Credited. 
    Payments received on statements shall be credited in the following manner: 
A.  The payment shall first be credited to the "other charges" portion of the account in the amount of any outstanding balance. 
B.  Any excess after application to subsection A shall then be credited to the portion of the account relating to the mosquito control charge in the amount of any outstanding balance. 
C.  Any excess after application to subsection B shall then be credited to the portion of the account relating to fees and contracts for collection and removal of garbage and refuse in the amount of any outstanding balance. 
D.  Any excess after application to subsection C of this section shall then be credited to the portion of the account relating to fees for use of dump grounds in the amount of any outstanding balance. 
E.  Any excess after application to subsection D of this section shall then be credited to the portion of the account relating to charges for use of sewer utility in the amount of any outstanding balance. 
F.  Any excess after application to subsection E of this section shall then be credited to the portion of the account relating to charges for water utility use. 
(Prior code § 12-13) 
13.40.070 - Payment-Responsibility-Penalty for failure. 
    Property owners or the owner, agent, tenant, purchaser or lessee of each such place of abode or place of business shall, each and all, be jointly and severally liable for the payment of all charges and fees hereunder. Failure to pay any charges and fees when due shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this chapter. Collection of the charges and fees fixed under the code when delinquent may be enforced by civil action at law brought by the city or an accredited collection agency for the city in any court of competent jurisdiction, and this remedy is cumulative and not exclusive and shall be in addition to all penalties provided by the code for any violation of any provisions hereof. No change of ownership or occupation shall affect the application of this section. 
(Prior code § 12-14) 
Chapter 13.44 - WATER SERVICE CHARGES 
Sections: 

13.44.010 - Rate schedules. 
A.  The charges for water service within the corporate boundaries of the city shall be based upon the size of the meter through which the water flows to provide service to the customer, together with a charge for the consumption of water provided. 
1.  There shall be a base charge per month for each meter of the following respective amounts: 
Meter Size 
(inches) January 1, 2017 January 1, 2018 3/4 21.83 23.16 1 36.01 38.51 11/2 62.23 66.53 2 94.25 100.79 3 203.59 218.18 4 332.41 355.84 6 600.30 627.62 8 871.30 889.78  
i.  A water shutoff for a seasonal user shall not stop base fee meter charges. 
2.  Water consumption shall be charged through the meter per one thousand gallons in the following amounts that shall be increased in the following year in the respective amounts beginning on January 1: 
Customer Class January 1, 2017 January 1, 2017 Inside Single Family First 3,000 gallons 3.76 3.76 4,000 to 6,000 gallons 4.69 4.69 7,000 to 24,000 gallons 5.88 5.88 Over 24,000 gallons 8.82 8.82 Multifamily 3.69 3.69 Commercial 3.97 3.97 University 4.05 4.05 Wholesale 4.85 4.85 Irrigation 7.26 7.76  
B.  For water delivered outside the corporate boundaries of the city, the charges shall be one hundred twenty-five percent of the in-city charges, if not separately contracted with the city. 
C.  The charges under subsection 1. of this section shall be payable in advance. Charges under subsection 2. of this section shall be billed and payable following the billing period during which water was delivered. 
(Prior code § 39-61; Ord. 556 § 1, 1978; Ord. 586 § 1, 1979; Ord. 952 § 1, 1988; Ord. 1222 § 1, 1997; Ord. 1317 § 1, 2000; Ord. 1362 § 1, 2001; Ord. 1389, § 1, 2002; Ord. 1430 § 1, 2004; Ord. 1463 § 1, 2005; Ord. 1488 § 1, 2006; Ord. No. 1531, § 1, 7-15-2008; Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 1593, § 1, 1-4-2011; Ord. No. 1603, § 1, 8-2-2011; Ord. No. 1651, § 1, 10-15-2013; Ord. No. 1675 , § 1, 12-16-2014; Ord. No. 1724 , § 2, 12-20-2016) 
13.44.020 - Billing periods. 
    The water utility shall bill water users not less than once every three months and not more often than once a month. 
(Prior code § 39-60) 
13.44.030 - Cost determination when meter defective. 
    Where a meter is broken or defective or for any reason does not correctly measure and record all the water used on any premises in any one quarter or where the proper city employee is unable to enter and read the meter after two attempts to read the meter, the charge for water used on such premises during that quarter shall be as follows: 
A.  Residential users shall be charged an amount based on the average consumption for residential users for the same quarter during the previous three years. 
B.  Users other than residential shall be charged an amount based on consumption the same quarter the preceding year if a meter was then in use and the use of the premises is the same as the preceding year. 
C.  In all other instances, the user shall be charged an amount based on the city treasurer's estimate of consumption. 
(Prior code § 39-62) 
13.44.040 - Disconnection or reconnection-Fee. 
    When water is once turned on to any premises, there shall be a charge of ten dollars for water shutoff or turn on during normal work hours and a charge of twenty-five dollars for water shutoff or turn on after normal work hours. 
(Prior code § 39-66; Ord. 707 § 1, 1982) 
13.44.050 - Annual debt service and water use. 
    The city council finds that the annual debt service for water system improvements for the city of Laramie is six hundred thirty four thousand dollars. The city's water rates are intended to include adequate provision for debt service in times of normal water use. The state climatologist, the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration, and the U.S. Geological Survey state that the areas which provide municipal water for the City of Laramie are within a drought warning area. In 2002, the Laramie River had the lowest flow in one hundred years at Woods Landing, just above the city's municipal water diversion. The city council recently adopted an ordinance to allow the imposition of mandatory outdoor water use restrictions. If those restrictions are successful, Laramie water customers will use less water, reducing the city's ability to make its debt service payments. The water utility loans are secured by mortgages and security interests in the city's water system. If any of the loans go into default, the Wyoming Water Development Commission could foreclose and either become the owner of the city's water utility or sell it to another party. It is not in the city's best interest to lose control of its water service utility. To assure timely repayment of the loans in times of drought, the city must maintain adequate water revenues in times of reduced water use. 
(Ord. 1415 § 1, 2003) 
13.44.060 - Water rate surcharge. 
    The city council may adopt resolutions to impose, remove and reimpose water rate surcharges during the months of May through October in response to identified drought conditions. The purpose of water rate surcharges is to assure the repayment of water utility indebtedness in times of reduced water use and to encourage municipal water conservation. Each resolution shall specify the duration of the surcharge, which shall be in increments of regular water meter readings. Council may extend or terminate the surcharge at any time by resolution. 
(Ord. 1415 § 2, 2003) 
13.44.070 - Surcharge rate-Consumption. 
    When the city council adopts a resolution finding that a municipal water conservation emergency exists and that a surcharge should be imposed, all municipal water rates for all water users and districts connected to the City's municipal water supply shall pay a surcharge based upon consumption as follows: 
A.  All residential customers shall pay a surcharge of $0.83 per thousand gallons for all water used during any month in which outdoor water use restrictions are in effect. The residential customer surcharge applies to customers which are water districts as well. If an outdoor water use restriction is in effect during any portion of a month, the surcharge will be imposed for all water use during that month. 
B.  All commercial accounts (excluding water districts which have commercial accounts) shall pay a surcharge of forty-two cents per thousand gallons for all water used during any month in which outdoor water use restrictions are in effect. If an outdoor water use restriction is in effect during any portion of a month, the surcharge will be imposed for all water use during that month. 
(Ord. 1415 § 3, 2003) 
13.44.080 - Drought surcharges. 
    All drought surcharges collected under this chapter shall be placed in a separate account and shall be used solely for repayment of water utility secured indebtedness. 
(Ord. 1415 § 5, 2003) 
13.44.090 - Low income affordable municipal services rates. 
A.  Notwithstanding the charges for municipal water service established elsewhere in this code, eligible households as defined in this ordinance shall receive a monthly credit of thirty-seven dollars and fifty-eight cents towards the municipal services bill. 
B.  Households where the applicant meets these criteria are eligible households: 
1.  The applicant must own the property where municipal services are being billed. 
2.  The applicant must reside at the address for at least nine months per year. 
3.  Municipal utilities must be billed to the applicant. 
4.  The applicant must be able to demonstrate current enrollment in a federal program in which a low income is a necessary qualification. Accepted programs are Social Security Supplemental Security Income (SSI), Women, Infants, and Children (WIC), Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP), and Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). The city will also accept other federal income assistance programs as proof at the discretion of the city manager or city manager's designee. 
5.  The applicant must not have any delinquent amount associated with his or her municipal services billing account. 
6.  The applicant shall submit an application and supporting documentation to the city. 
7.  The city manager, or city manager's designee, shall be responsible for reviewing all applications, as well as approving complete and qualifying applications. 
C.  Each applicant for the water rates established by this section shall complete and submit an application to the city upon a form prescribed by the finance division. The form shall request the information necessary to establish eligibility and shall be verified under oath by the applicant. The following supporting information shall be submitted with the application. 
1.  Proof of current enrollment in a federal program in which a low income is a necessary qualification. 
D.  Households receiving the rate established in this section shall report to the city any change in circumstance which makes them ineligible. The applicant must reapply for the program on an annual basis, with the reapply deadline set for the first of June every year. 
(Ord. No. 1640, §§ 1-4, 2-19-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1640, §§ 1-4, adopted Feb. 19, 2013, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 13.44.090 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 13.48 - SEWER SERVICE CHARGES[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

13.48.010 - Rate schedules. 
A.  The user rates are hereby established to be charged as follows:

(Ord. 429 § 6 (part), 1973; Ord. 667 § 1(f), 1981; Ord. 697 1(f), 1982; Ord. 1004 § 1(f), 1990; Ord. No. 1565, § 1, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 1594, § 1, 1-4-2011; Ord. No. 1604, § 1, 8-2-2011; Ord. No. 1623, § 1, 8-7-2012; Ord. No. 1725 , § 1, 12-20-2016; Ord. No. 1740 , § 1, 12-5-2017) 
13.48.012 - Wastes prohibited from being discharged to the wastewater treatment system. 
A.  The discharge of any waters containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly, or by interaction with other wastes, to contaminate the sludge of any municipal system, or to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in or have an adverse effect on the waters receiving any discharge from the treatment works is prohibited. 
B.  All industries as identified by EPA's Industrial Categorical Listing in 40 CFR Part 403 are required to have pretreatment to eliminate the discharge of any wastes described above to treatment works. 
C.  Each user which discharges any toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the cost of treating the waste or managing the effluent or the sludge of the city's treatment works shall pay for such increased costs. 
(Ord. 429 § 6 (part), 1973; Ord. 667 § 1(g), 1981; Ord. 697 § l(g), 1982; Ord. 1004 § 1(g), 1990) 
13.48.014 - Prohibition of clear water connections. 
    No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, area-way drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. 429 § 6 (part), 1973; Ord. 1004 § 1(h), 1990: Ord. 697 § 1(h), 1982: Ord. 667 § 1(h), 1981) 
13.48.016 - Proper design and construction of new sewers and connections. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of all sanitary sewers and sewer connections, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city and the state. In the absence of code provision or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the A.S.T.M. and W.P.C.F. Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(Ord. 429 § 6 (part), 1973; Ord. 667 § 1(i), 1981; Ord. 697 § 1(i), 1982; Ord. 1004 § 1(i), 1990) 
13.48.018 - [Wastewater] rate schedules. 
A.  The user rates are hereby established to be charged as follows: 
B.  Base Rate. The monthly base charge for residential and nonresidential users shall be in accordance with the following table:

Editor's note- In order to avoid duplication of section titles, and at the editor's discretion, § 13.48.018 "Rate schedules" has been changed to "[Wastewater] rate schedules." 
13.48.019 - Surcharge for above normal strength wastes. 
A.  Schedule A. The city will assess a surcharge rate for all nonresidential users discharging wastes with BOD and TSS strengths greater than those specified in Section 13.48.006 for normal strength wastes of residential users. The surcharge will be sufficient to cover the costs of treating such users' above normal strength wastes. Such users will pay an additional service charge of six and three-tenth cents per one thousand gallons for each twenty-five mg/l over two hundred mg/l of BOD. There is no additional charge for excess TSS. 
B.  Schedule B. Residential users are considered to be one class of user and are assessed a base charge as set out in Section 13.48.018. All nonresidential users will pay the same base charge as the residential user as set out in Section 13.48.018. 
(Ord. 429 § 6 (part), 1973; Ord. 667 § 1(k, l), 1981; Ord. 697 § 1(k, l), 1982; Ord. 1004 § 1(k, l), 1990; Ord. 1206 § 2, 1997; Ord. 1272 § 2, 1999; Ord. 1318 § 2, 2000; Ord. 1363 § 2, 2001; Ord. 1390 § 2, 2002; Ord. 1419 § 2, 2003; Ord. 1431 § 2, 2004; Ord. 1489 § 2, 2006; Ord. 1517 § 2, 2007) 
13.48.020 - Service outside city. 
    The charges for sewer service outside the corporate limits shall be one hundred twenty-five percent of the charges within the corporate limits, unless otherwise provided by the city council. 
(Prior code § 32-35; Ord. 1489 § 3, 2006) 
13.48.030 - Water entering system from private wells. 
    The city manager may require that water used from private wells which enters the sanitary sewer system shall be metered or he may otherwise determine the method to be used to establish the rate to be charged for sewer service. 
(Prior code § 32-36) 
13.48.040 - Water bill not accepted unless accompanied by sewer charges. 
    The sewer service charges provided for in this chapter shall be paid with the water bill. The city shall not accept payment of the water bill unless the charges for sewer services are included therewith. 
(Prior code § 32-39) 
13.48.050 - Failure to pay may result in loss of water services. 
    No person shall be permitted to use water from the water utility if the sewer charges provided by this chapter have not been paid. 
(Prior code § 32-40) 
Chapter 13.50 - PERMIT FEES 
Sections: 

13.50.010 - Permit required for connection. 
A.  No person shall connect, or cause a connection to be made to the water or sewer system of the city without first having obtained a permit from the office of the city engineer. 
B.  The permit shall be on a form prescribed by the city engineer which shall provide that connections shall be made in accordance with specifications and subject to the supervision, inspection and acceptance of the city engineer or his designated representative. 
(Ord. 664 § 1 (part), 1981; Ord. 706 § 1(a), 1982) 
13.50.020 - Fees-Payment. 
A.  All persons applying for a permit to connect to the city's water or sewer system, or to increase the size or number of connections to an existing premise, shall pay to the city a connection charge to the city's water or sewer system (plant investment fee) for each premise served. Plant investment fees shall be based upon the size of the largest water meter on each water service required to provide nonfirewater demand for the premise to be served. 
    Plant investment fees shall be charged and paid as a condition of the issuance of a permit for water and sewer system connections. The payment of the plant investment fees shall be at the time a permit is issued to connect to the city's water or sewer system. For a new premise, a permit to connect to the city's water or sewer system shall not be issued until after a valid building permit has been issued for that particular premise. 
    The city manager, or the manager's designee, may promulgate such rules, regulations and policies as they consider necessary to allow for the payment of plant investment fees in installments over a reasonable period of time. 
    Water meter sizing and water supply piping shall conform to the plumbing code most recently adopted and enforced by the city of Laramie. At the request of the city manager, or the city manager's designee, the applicant shall provide any and all information required (i.e., fixtures units, pipe sizing, etc.) to assure compliance with the plumbing code. 
B.  The plant investment fees for connections inside the corporate boundaries of the city shall be as shown in the following schedule: 
Size of Water Meter Plant Investment Fees Based Upon Water Meter Size Water Sewer 3/4" $ 3,021.00 $ 2,811.00 1" 5,045.00 4,694.00 1 1/2" 10,070.00 9,370.00 2" 16,112.00 14,992.00 3" 30,210.00 28,110.00 4" 50,350.00 46,850.00 6" 75,525.00 70,275.00  
    Those persons applying to increase the size of an existing connection or water meter shall receive credit for the value of the existing connection or water meter based upon the preceding schedule. 
C.  Plant investment fees for connections extended beyond the corporate boundaries of the city shall be assessed as stated within Section 13.50.040 of this chapter. 
D.  All plant investment fees collected shall be placed into a separate account entitled plant investment fees within the water and wastewater fund. These plant investment fees shall be used only to pay for replacements and additions to the city waterworks, sanitary sewer system, and sewage disposal plants. Replacements and additions shall be capitalized and the capital value added to the value of the systems to establish the value of the plants for depreciation purposes. 
(Ord. 664 § 1 (part), 1981; Ord. 706 § 1 (b), 1982; Ord. 1457 § 1, 2005) 
13.50.040 - Beyond corporate boundaries of city. 
    Plant investment fees for connections extended beyond the corporate boundaries of the city shall be one hundred twenty-five percent of the fees set forth in Section 13.50.020(B) 
(Ord. 664 § 3, 1981; Ord. 1457 § 3, 2005) 
13.50.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be punished pursuant to the provisions of Section 1.28.010. 
(Ord. 664 § 5, 1981) 
Chapter 13.52 - MOSQUITO CONTROL 
Sections: 

13.52.010 - Generally. 
    There is assessed to the account of each utility user, whether such account relates to service inside or outside the corporate limits, a charge of four dollars and eighty-nine cents per month per account, payable in advance, commencing April 1, 2016, for mosquito control. The monthly charge shall be billed and payable with the city's regular utility account billings. 
(Prior code § 12-8; Ord. 1097 § 1, 1993; Ord. 1275 § 1, 1999; Ord. No. 1537, § 1, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 1582, § 1, 4-20-2010; Ord. No. 1701 , § 1, 3-1-2016) 
Division IV. - Solid Waste[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, changed the title of Div. IV from "City Dump" to "Solid Waste." 

Chapter 13.54 - SOLID WASTE-GENERAL 

13.54.010 - Purpose of flow control. 
    The city has undertaken a study of its solid waste collection and disposal systems to provide the best service available to its citizens at the lowest reasonable cost to the customers. In order to assure that the garbage and refuse that is being generated within the city is properly and efficiently disposed of, as well as support of the recycling program is being performed, it is important that the entire amount of garbage and refuse be collected and deposited within the disposal system operated by the city, unless specifically exempted by ordinance, as the fee rate structure is dependent upon the volume that is accumulated and disposed of in the system. The designed system insures the most public benefit with the greatest health protection that is reasonably available to the city for the benefit and protection of the public. The authority for such provisions is found in W.S. 15-1-103. 
(Ord. No. 1635, § 1, 1-2-2013) 
13.54.020 - Prohibited activities. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided within this title [chapter], it shall be unlawful for any licensed waste hauler or individual to transport solid waste that has been generated within the city limits, or within one-half-mile of said limits, to any solid waste facility or disposal site other than the landfill as is operated by the city from time to time. 
B.  It is unlawful for any solid waste generator, hauler, contractor or other person to falsely state, or to direct another person to state, to an employee or operator of the landfill that waste was generated outside the city limits, or that area within one-half-mile of the limits, when, in fact, the waste was generated within the city limits, or within one-half-mile of the limits. 
(Ord. No. 1635, § 2, 1-2-2013) 
13.54.030 - Exceptions. 
    Waste that is generated within the city limits, or within one-half-mile of the city limits may be transported to another waste facility or disposal site under the following conditions: 
A.  The waste is of a type or nature that is not accepted at the city landfill because of restrictions by the department of environmental quality, including, but not limited to: 
a.  Hazardous waste. 
b.  Petroleum contaminated waste products. 
B.  The person or waste hauler has received a permit from the city manager to transport specified waste to an identified disposal site prior to beginning the transport for reasons that are identified on the permit. Such reasons may include a more efficient disposal of the waste, or disposal of an undesirable product of waste. 
(Ord. No. 1635, § 3, 1-2-2013) 
13.54.040 - Penalties. 
    A violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars, and may include the suspension or revocation of an issued solid waste collector's license, or refusal to issue a solid waste collector's license. 
(Ord. No. 1635, § 4, 1-2-2013) 
Chapter 13.56 - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, changed the title of Ch. 13.56 from "General Provisions" to "Solid Waste Collection." 

13.56.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
A.  "Container" refers to any disposable bag, box, or similar item into which refuse is placed prior to being placed within a receptacle. 
B.  "Garbage" means and includes all kitchen refuse, rejected or waste food, meats, fish, fowl, offal, carrion or other refuse accumulation, use, cooking of or the dealing in or storing of meats, fish, fowl, fruits, vegetables or anything whatsoever which will or may decompose and become foul, offensive, insanitary or dangerous to health. 
C.  "Receptacle" means any non-disposable container used for the purpose of containing refuse. 
D.  "Refuse" means and includes all hay, straw, shavings, excelsior, paper, ashes, rubbish, containers, boxes, glass, cans, bottles and the residue from the burning or other destruction of all combustible material whatsoever, and all other material commonly known as rubbish or refuse of whatever kind or character or by whatever name known, except as excluded by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, §§ 1, 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.010 as § 13.56.010. 
13.56.020 - Containers-Required. 
A.  For residences and/or businesses with a manual refuse collection service. All such persons, where cooking or eating is done, shall provide and keep at their expense, at all times, garbage cans or acceptable receptacles which in the discretion of the city manager or designee are suitable for the purpose of holding all garbage and refuse without running over. 
B.  For residences and/or businesses with automated collection and curbside recycling. The city will provide customers with a standard collection receptacle compatible with automated collection equipment. Only receptacles provided by the city shall be used for automated collection and curbside recycling. the city is responsible for repair and replacement of receptacles damaged or worn as a result of normal use. The city may require customers to pay for repair or replacement of receptacles damaged or destroyed through customer negligence. The replacement cost for missing containers shall be billed to and paid by the person assigned to the container. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.030 as § 13.56.020. 
13.56.030 - Securing garbage, refuse and other materials. 
A.  All garbage, refuse or other disposable materials must be properly prepared for collection and contained to avoid littering. To avoid blowing of loose debris, each residence must contain all garbage, refuse or other disposable materials in a securely tied or sealed disposable bag or container. Such disposable bag or container must be of a material of sufficient thickness and strength to contain the refuse enclosed without tearing or ripping under normal handling. All garbage, refuse or other disposable materials must be placed in a disposable bag or container before being placed in a trash receptacle for collection and all trash receptacles must be covered with a lid. It is the responsibility of the property owner or resident to repackage torn disposable bags or containers or tipped trash receptacles in a timely manner in order to properly contain the materials for collection. 
B.  Brush from tree limbs or bushes may be tied in bundles not more than three feet long and weighing not more than twenty-five pounds each. 
C.  All glass, all sharp corners and all sharp items shall be securely wrapped to prevent injury to any person collecting the refuse. 
D.  It shall be unlawful to place any household hazardous waste or hazardous waste in receptacles. Such materials shall be disposed of in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local statutes. 
E.  The owner or occupant of the premises shall be deemed to be responsible for any violation of or failure to comply with any of the requirements of this section. Garbage, refuse or disposable materials set out for collection which does not meet the requirements outlined herein will not be collected and a notice will be placed on the trash receptacle, bag or container. After two or more notices of failure to comply with the section herein, the city shall not collect any garbage, refuse or disposable materials of the owner or occupant of the premises until compliance is met. If debris is scattered, the resident must abate or the city may clean up the debris and charge the owner or occupant of the premises a fee of twenty-five dollars for the abatement. 
F.  For automated collection, the combined weight of each solid waste receptacle and the contents shall not exceed three hundred fifty pounds; the contents shall securely fit into the receptacle so that the lid closes completely. 
G.  Heavy metals or metal parts, lumber, rocks, bricks, concrete blocks, tires, sod, dirt, gravel, dead animals, and materials from construction or remodeling shall not be placed in the solid waste receptacle. These items shall be delivered to the landfill for proper disposal. 
H.  Boxes and crates shall be dismantled, flattened, or otherwise compacted prior to placement in solid waste receptacles. 
I.  For both manual and automated collection, only refuse placed into city approved (manual collection) or city provided (automated collection) receptacles will be collected as part of the normal collection route. 
J.  All charcoal or ashes from barbecue pits, fireplaces or other sources must be thoroughly cold or doused with water before being placed in receptacles. The customer is responsible for replacement of city provided receptacles damaged as a result of hot ashes or coals. 
K.  For curbside recycling, only accepted materials may be placed into the containers for pick up. Acceptable materials include: plastic #1-#7, aluminum beverage cans and foil, steel cans, newspapers, magazines, phone books, white paper, shredded paper, office pack, corrugated cardboard, paperboard, brown paper bags. 
L.  Items not accepted include: glass, plastic bags, packing peanuts. Glass can be recycled separately through alternate local private facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.040 as § 13.56.030. 
13.56.040 - Receptacles-Specifications. 
A.  For manual refuse collection, all trash receptacles shall be constructed of galvanized iron, metal, plastic or other material approved by the city manager or designee, shall have a lid or cover; shall have a bail or handles thereon for handling: and shall not exceed thirty-two gallons in capacity, and fifty pounds in weight when loaded. 
B.  In areas where manual garbage collection is conducted in the front of a residence and from the street, the number of bags placed at the curbside shall not exceed sixty-four gallons. 
C.  For automated collection, receptacles shall be furnished and supplied by the city and shall be of the type, size and color specified for use. 
D.  Garbage, refuse, recycled materials, or disposable materials set out for collection which does not meet the requirements outlined herein will not be collected and a notice will be placed on the trash receptacle, bag or container. After two or more notices of failure to comply with the section herein, the city shall not collect any garbage, refuse, recycled materials, or disposable materials of the owner or occupant of the premises until compliance is met. Residents and businesses are responsible for controlling waste until it is picked up by the solid waste department. If debris is scattered, the owner or occupant of the premises must abate or the city may clean up the debris and charge the owner or occupant of the premises a fee of twenty-five dollars for the abatement. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.050 as § 13.56.040. 
13.56.050 - Receptacles-Location-Security. 
A.  All manual collection receptacles shall be placed in a location within the lot line adjacent to the alley and within easy reach, or, where there is no access to the alley, at some other proper and accessible place within easy reach of the garbage collector. Such receptacles shall be secured upon a rack or base in such a manner as to provide reasonable security against being overturned by animals, wind or other causes. 
B.  All automated collection receptacles shall be placed within the lot line adjacent to the alley for alley collection. For street-side collection, the receptacles shall be placed at the curb line at a distance of two feet minimum from any parked vehicle. For multiple receptacles, a minimum separation of two feet shall be required between each container. Receptacles shall not be placed on sidewalks. Location of receptacles for collection, either curbside or alley, shall be made by the city manager or designee. 
C.  All containers shall be placed for collection no later than seven o'clock a.m. on the day that garbage collection is scheduled and shall be removed by six o'clock p.m. of the same day, or when emptied, whichever is later. 
D.  For automated collection, the customer shall roll out the receptacle to be placed at the designated location on the day scheduled for collection. If the receptacle is not placed to allow for collection by the city's automated process, the city shall be deemed to have provided service whether or not the container is emptied. Request to return and empty any such receptacle shall be considered a special collection with an added fee of fifteen dollars. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.060 as § 13.56.050. 
13.56.060 - Receptacles-Placing of liquids. 
    No liquids shall be placed in any receptacle for collection in the residential districts. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.070 as § 13.56.060. 
13.56.070 - Occupancy taken as proof of refuse accumulation. 
A.  Any occupied place of abode, any place of business in operation or any construction site shall be prima facie evidence that garbage and refuse is being produced and accumulated on such premises. It shall be the duty of the city manager or designee to inspect and supervise such premises and to remove or cause to be removed there from all garbage or refuse found on the premises and in the adjoining streets and alleys, and to assess and collect a reasonable charge therefore from the abutting owner, agent, tenant, purchaser, contractor or lessee. 
B.  The owner of the property where waste is generated is responsible for the proper disposal of the waste regardless of whether the owner resides on the property. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.080 as § 13.56.070. 
13.56.080 - Hauling-Restricted to city-Exceptions. 
A.  Except as provided in Section 8.16.110, all garbage and refuse accumulated within the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the city under the supervision of the city manager or designee, and it is unlawful for any person to move over, upon or across any street or alley within the city any garbage or refuse, except representatives of the city; provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to persons hauling their own garbage or refuse from their homes or places of business or from construction sites. 
B.  All vehicles used for the transportation of refuse shall be fully enclosed or covered in such a manner as to prevent the spilling or blowing of refuse. Any person arriving at the city disposal site not meeting this regulation may be assessed a ten-dollar fee in addition to any other standard disposal fees. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.090 as § 13.56.080. 
13.56.090 - Hauling-Contracting for nonsingle-kitchen units. 
    Construction site owners or contractors, places of business, hotels, motels, schools, institutions, trailer courts and apartments containing more than two kitchen units, may contract with licensed collectors for the removal of garbage, refuse and other material through the city streets, or make arrangements for city services with the city manager or designee. Residences containing two or fewer kitchen units shall be required to utilize city refuse collection, disposal, and curbside recycling services. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.100 as § 13.56.090. 
13.56.100 - Collection-Temporary termination. 
    Garbage collection and removal may be temporarily terminated upon notification to the city treasurer for periods over thirty-days credit prorated will be given after service is resumed at the request of the customer. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.170 as § 13.56.100. 
13.56.110 - Use of receptacle belonging to another forbidden. 
    No person shall deposit garbage or refuse in any garbage or refuse receptacle owned, leased, or provided for the use of another, without the permission of the owner, lessee, or person for whose use the receptacle is provided. This section does not apply to the use of garbage or refuse receptacles which are intended for public use. Persons convicted of a violation of this section are subject to the general penalty section of this code. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.240 as § 13.56.110. 
13.56.120 - Refuse removal refusal. 
    No owner, tenant or lessee shall refuse or neglect to permit the removal of garbage or refuse from their premises. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.250 as § 13.56.120. 
13.56.130 - Purpose-Enforcement. 
    This chapter is declared to be strictly a sanitary measure for the promotion and protection of the public health and safety and to prevent fire hazards and nuisances. The city council shall use every means at its disposal, including its police powers, for the enforcement of this chapter and may revoke the licenses of licensed haulers for the violation of any provisions of this code or other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 2, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.260 as § 13.56.130. 
Chapter 13.60 - SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 20, 2011, changed the title of Ch. 13.60 from "City Dump Fees" to "Solid Waste Disposal." 

13.60.010 - Established. 
    There is established a city dump ground for the city: NW1/4, NW1/4, W1/2, NE1/4, N1/2, SW1/4, NW1/4, NW1/4, NW1/4, SE1/4, NW1/4, Section 22, Township 16 North, Range 73 West of the 6th P.M., to be used for the disposal of all ashes, refuse, garbage and other waste matter or materials. 
(Prior code § 15-22; Ord. No. 1611, § 3, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 12. 2011, renumbered former § 13.56.010 as § 13.60.010. 
13.60.020 - Regulatory authority. 
    The city manager is authorized to establish rules and regulations for the operation of the city dump ground and its use by the public. 
(Prior code § 15-23; Ord. No. 1611, § 3, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 12. 2011, renumbered former § 13.56.020 as § 13.60.020. 
13.60.030 - Deposits become city's property-Removal prohibited. 
    All garbage, refuse, waste or matter of any kind disposed of at the city dump ground shall become the property of the city, and no person shall separate, collect, carry off or otherwise remove or dispose of anything whatsoever from the city dump ground without the permission of the city manager or his duly authorized representative. 
(Prior code § 15-24; Ord. No. 1611, § 3, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 12. 2011, renumbered former § 13.56.030 as § 13.60.030. 
13.60.040 - Off-dump dumping-Prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use other land or places within the limits of the city for the purpose of dumping ashes, refuse, garbage, waste or other matter, than the dump ground provided in this division. 
(Prior code § 15-25; Ord. No. 1611, § 3, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 12. 2011, renumbered former § 13.56.040 as § 13.60.040. 
13.60.050 - Setting fires. 
    It is unlawful to set a fire within the city dump ground without the permission of the city manager or his duly authorized representative. 
(Prior code § 15-26; Ord. No. 1611, § 3, 12-20-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 12. 2011, renumbered former § 13.56.050 as § 13.60.050. 
13.60.060 - Nonresidents using the landfill. 
    The city of Laramie landfill may accept waste from outside of Laramie city limits and Albany County, Wyoming by residents, nonresidents, and businesses as outlined in the landfill operating permit. The city manager or designee reserves the right to refuse waste disposal by any individual or business to reduce liability exposure and ensure financially sound operating practices of the city of Laramie landfill. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 1611, § 3, 12-20-2011; Ord. No. 1673 , 11-18-2014) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 1611, adopted Dec. 12. 2011, renumbered former § 8.16.150 as § 13.60.060. 
Chapter 13.62 - SOLID WASTE FEES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1716 , adopted Aug. 15, 2016, amended Ch. 13.62 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 13.62, §§ 13.62.010-13.62.100 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 1656, adopted March 4, 2014. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation. 

13.62.010 - Collection fees-Households-Generally. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
A.  "Construction and demolition (c&d) debris" is debris that results from the construction, renovation and/or demolition of buildings, roads, bridges, fences or other structures. It includes (but is not limited to) brick, concrete, asphalt material, drywall, flooring, pipe, lumber, roofing, soil and rocks. 
B.  "Container" refers to any disposable bag, box, or similar item into which refuse is placed prior to being placed within a receptacle. 
C.  "Garbage" means and includes all kitchen refuse, rejected or waste food, meats, fish, fowl, offal, carrion or other refuse accumulation, use, cooking of or the dealing in or storing of meats, fish, fowl, fruits, vegetables or anything whatsoever which will or may decompose and become foul, offensive, insanitary or dangerous to health. 
D.  "Receptacle" means any non-disposable container used for the purpose of containing refuse. 
E.  "Refuse" means and includes all hay, straw, shavings, excelsior, paper, ashes, rubbish, containers, boxes, glass, cans, bottles and the residue from the burning or other destruction of all combustible material whatsoever, and all other material commonly known as rubbish or refuse of whatever kind or character or by whatever name known, except as excluded by this chapter. 
F.  "Kitchen unit" means the main function of a kitchen unit serves as a location for storing, cooking and preparing food. A residential kitchen unit is typically equipped with a cooking appliance, a sink with running water, a refrigerator, counters and cabinets. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
13.62.020 - Same-Basic receptacles. 
A.  Except in cases where contracts have been entered into with licensed haulers as provided in Section 8.16.110, all households utilizing automated collection within the city shall be charged the following fees for the supervision and regular once-per-week pickup of garbage and refuse, and bi-weekly pickup of curbside recyclables which shall be prorated on a weekly basis. 
B.  For all households utilizing automated collection, fees shall apply to once-per-week pickup. 
C.  For automated refuse collection from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017, the basic fee of nine dollars and sixteen cents per month shall be assessed for one city provided receptacle with a total capacity of ninety-six gallons, in addition to the landfill fees. 
D.  For automated refuse collection beginning January 1, 2018, the basic fee of nine dollars and thirty-four cents per month shall be assessed for one city provided receptacle with a total capacity of ninety-six gallons, in addition to the landfill fees. 
E.  For curbside recycling from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017, a fee of four dollars and thirty-nine cents per month shall be assessed for one receptacle. 
F.  For curbside recycling beginning January 1, 2018, a fee of four dollars and forty-eight cents per month shall be assessed for one receptacle. 
G.  Automated trash and recycling containers must be placed a minimum of two feet from any object, i.e., vehicles, trailers, fences, poles, trees, other containers, etc., and be sure the area in front of the container (toward the street) is clear of obstructions. A container placement fee of five dollars may be charged each time a driver must exit the vehicle to move a container so it may be safely dumped without striking a nearby object. The fee will not apply if a container is blown over by the wind or other act of nature. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
13.62.030 - Same-Additional receptacles. 
A.  For automated refuse collection from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017, the sum of nine dollars and sixteen cents per month shall be assessed for each additional receptacle in addition to the landfill fees. 
B.  For automated refuse collection beginning January 1, 2018, the sum of nine dollars and thirty-four cents per month shall be assessed for each additional receptacle in addition to the landfill fees. 
C.  For curbside recycling from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017, a fee of four dollars and thirty-nine cents per month shall be assessed for each additional receptacle. 
D.  For curbside recycling beginning January 1, 2018, a fee of four dollars and forty-eight cents per month shall be assessed for each additional receptacle. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
13.62.040 - Collection fees-Non-single kitchen units or businesses. 
    Where there is more than one kitchen unit at one street address or in the same building, the owner must assume liability for the garbage fee for all the units. The fees for each city provided receptacle with a total capacity of ninety-six gallons shall be nine dollars and sixteen cents per month plus a separate landfill disposal fee for each kitchen unit as provided in [Section] 13.62.070, from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017. 
    Where there is more than one kitchen unit at one street address or in the same building, the owner must assume liability for the garbage fee for all the units. The fees for each city provided receptacle with a total capacity of ninety-six gallons shall be nine dollars and thirty-four cents per month plus a separate landfill disposal fee for each kitchen unit as provided in [section] 13.62.070, beginning January 1, 2018. 
    At the request of the owner, the city may provide curbside recycling services to places of business, hotels, motels, schools, institutions, trailer courts and residences or apartments containing more than two kitchen units and the fee shall be four dollars and thirty-nine cents per receptacle per month from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017, and shall be four dollars and forty-eight cents per receptacle per month beginning January 1, 2018. Residences containing two or fewer kitchen units shall be required to utilize city refuse, collection, disposal and curbside recycling services. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
13.62.050 - Same-Petition for waiver. 
    Upon petition accompanied by an affidavit to the extent that any individual does not have the financial capacity to pay the fees for collection of garbage and refuse as they are set forth in this chapter, the city manager may in its sole discretion, adjust or completely waive the fees therein contained. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
_____
13.62.060 - Collection rate schedule for city-provided commercial receptacles. 
A.  The city will, upon request, provide receptacles for rental at the following monthly rates based upon receptacle size and frequency of collection as follows:

( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
_____
13.62.070 - Disposal fees-Generally. 
A.  The following landfill fees will be charged to all in-city users: 
1.  The sum of seven dollars and twenty-three cents per month, for up to ninety-six gallons capacity for a household unit containing one kitchen unit serving one family group, from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017; 
2.  The sum of seven dollars and eighty-two cents per month, for up to ninety-six gallons capacity for a household unit containing one kitchen unit serving one family group, beginning January 1, 2018; 
3.  Where there is more than one kitchen unit at one street address or in the same building, the owner must assume liability for the landfill fees for all the units, and the fee shall be seven dollars and twenty-three cents per month for each kitchen unit from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017; 
4.  Where there is more than one kitchen unit at one street address or in the same building, the owner must assume liability for the landfill fees for all the units, and the fee shall be seven dollars and eighty-two cents per month for each kitchen unit beginning January 1, 2018; 
5.  Places of business, hotels, motels, schools, and institutions in the city which have commercial refuse collection by the city shall be assessed disposal fees according to volume; payable per month: 
MONTHLY COMMERCIAL DISPOSAL RATES-2017
TWO CUBIC YARD AND LARGER 
CONTAINER 
SIZE COLLECTIONS PER WEEK 1 2 3 4 5 6 2 Cubic Yards $30.51 $61.01 $91.54 $122.04 $152.56 $183.06 4 Cubic Yards 61.02 122.03 183.06 244.09 305.11 366.13 6 Cubic Yards 91.61 183.06 274.60 366.13 457.67 549.20  
  
MONTHLY COMMERCIAL DISPOSAL RATES-BEGINNING 2018
TWO CUBIC YARD AND LARGER 
CONTAINER 
SIZE COLLECTIONS PER WEEK 1 2 3 4 5 6 2 Cubic Yards $32.60 $65.19 $97.79 $130.38 $162.99 $195.58 4 Cubic Yards 65.20 130.37 195.58 260.78 325.97 391.16 6 Cubic Yards 97.86 195.58 293.37 391.16 488.96 585.75  
B.  If a commercial customer requests an extra collection the charge shall be ten dollars per cubic yard. 
C.  The fee imposed by this subsection shall apply to all private businesses which haul material to the city landfill for profit; to all residents and nonresidents whose loads are accepted by the solid waste manager for disposal; to all governmental entities other than the city of Laramie; and, to all private businesses which haul material to the city landfill incidental to other goods or services which they provide (such as construction trades). 
    Each person or business who hauls any material to the city landfill for disposal, shall pay a fee of sixty dollars per ton with a minimum charge of twelve dollars per entry from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017. All cash transactions at the landfill will be rounded to the nearest dollar. 
    Each person or business who hauls any material to the city landfill for disposal, shall pay a fee of sixty-three dollars per ton with a minimum charge of twelve dollars per entry beginning January 1, 2018. All cash transactions at the landfill will be rounded to the nearest dollar. 
    Compacted waste shall include any construction and demolition debris delivered to the landfill. Any person or business that fails, neglects, or refuses to pay the required fee shall be denied access to the landfill until the fee is paid. 
    If the scale at the Laramie Landfill is inoperable for any reason, the rate for each person or business shall be four dollars and sixty-seven cents per cubic yard for uncompacted waste and sixteen dollars and thirty-three cents per cubic yard for compacted waste with a minimum charge of twelve dollars per entry. All cash transactions at the landfill will be rounded to the nearest dollar. 
D.  The solid waste manager or his designee shall impose a charge of ten dollars per ton with a ten-dollar minimum, if in his opinion the load is not adequately secured or contained to prevent the transported material from blowing or falling out of the vehicle. The fee established by this section is a charge to help with the cost of litter pickup and is not a criminal fine. 
E.  The solid waste manager or his designee may impose a charge of fifteen dollars per ton with a fifteen-dollar minimum for items that require special handling. Waste materials that require special handling or take extra care when handling include, but are not limited to, large and bulky items such as mobile homes, campers and trailers. Stumps and branches over eighteen inches in diameter and/or more than eight feet long may require special handling. Items that require special attention and/or immediate cover such as asbestos, petroleum contaminated soils and dead animals shall be considered special handling. 
F.  The solid waste manager may designate up to two days per calendar year as free compost days. Limitations on quantities, businesses and city or county will be set dependent on the supply of finished compost. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
13.62.080 - Tire disposal fees. 
A.  In addition to all other charges provided by law, the following landfill fees will be charged to all users: 
1.  Automobile and light truck tires, four dollars each. 
2.  Heavy truck and light industrial tires, ten dollars each. 
3.  Heavy equipment tires, seventy-five dollars each. 
4.  Mounted, solid or foam filled tires will double the fee. 
B.  Tire disposal fees shall be collected from the person who brings tires to the city landfill at the time the tires are brought to the landfill. 
C.  Tires shall be placed at a location designated by the city manager or designee and not at any other location. 
D.  Any person who disposes of a tire or tires without paying the required fee at the time of disposal, or who places tires upon property owned or controlled by the city in a location not designated for tire disposal is guilty of a violation of this section and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in the general penalty section of this code. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
13.62.090 - Landfill fee waiver. 
A.  The city manager, or designee, is authorized to waive such landfill fees for those events which are previously identified and approved by the office of the city manager, and contribute to the overall cleanliness and appearance of the community including the following instances: 
1.  Residential Voucher Program. A voucher program has been established and will be administered by the public works department/solid waste division. One voucher per residence per year. Vouchers are good for one free pick-up size (approximately two and one half cubic yards) load of waste and/or recyclable materials. Vouchers will not be issued to businesses. Vouchers will not be valid for tires, refrigerators, dead animals, special handling or uncovered load fees. 
2.  Any community clean-up activity wherein a group wishes to collect trash, litter, and other debris, at a specified time and date with prior authorization for waiver of fees upon delivery of the collected refuse to the city sanitary landfill. 
B.  Local groups may apply for approval of community service events by contacting the office of the city manager and completing the appropriate form. All fees for trash collected within the city limits on public property shall be waived for the approved event. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016; Ord. No. 1742 , § 1, 1-2-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1742 , § 1, adopted January 2, 2018, renamed § 13.62.090 from "community clean-up days fee waiver" to "landfill fee waiver." 
13.62.100 - Miscellaneous charges. 
A.  Disposal of refrigeration units-Thirty dollars and no cents. 
B.  Disposal of dead animals-The per ton fee shall be the same as disposal with a fifteen-dollar minimum. 
C.  Collections-Roll-off service with seven-yard container: two hundred dollars per load (includes delivery, pickup and disposal), containers held over fourteen days will be assessed an additional fee of five dollars per day. 
D.  Short term/special event polycart rental-Five dollars per cart/per dump and a twenty-five-dollar delivery charge for up to eight polycarts. 
E.  Business electronic waste recycling-Business rate is three hundred sixty dollars per ton. 
F.  Finished compost-Fifteen dollars per cubic yard or twenty-five dollars per ton with a one-dollar minimum. 
G.  Single stream recycling drop off-The per ton fee shall be the same as disposal with a minimum charge of five dollars. 
H.  No charge to residents: 
1.  Wood mulch. 
2.  Green waste for recycling. 
3.  Metal for recycling. 
4.  Household hazardous waste. 
5.  Residential electronic waste recycling. 
( Ord. No. 1716 , 8-15-2016) 
Division V. - Cemetery 
Chapter 13.64 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

13.64.010 - Designated. 
    The city cemetery, as the same is designated in the plat on file in the office of the county clerk and ex officio register of deeds of the county, is made and designated the city cemetery of the city. 
(Prior code § 10-1) 
13.64.015 - Definition. 
    "Cemetery" means a parcel of land which has been surveyed and platted, in the manner provided by law, as lots for the purpose of burying human remains. The term includes both public and private cemeteries. 
(Ord. 1166 § 1, 1995) 
13.64.020 - Establishment of additional rules and regulations. 
    The city manager may establish reasonable rules and regulations for the care, use and maintenance of the city cemetery in addition to the regulations established by city ordinance. 
(Ord. 884 § 13, 1987) 
13.64.030 - Sexton-Duties. 
    The city sexton shall keep a full, true and correct record and plat of the city cemetery and burial lots therein, showing the disposition of such lots for burial purposes and the interments made in each lot, with the name, age, sex and residence at the time of death of the interred therein. 
(Prior code § 10-3; Ord. 884 § 2, 1987) 
13.64.050 - Sexton-Monthly report. 
    The sexton shall, each month, render a full, true, correct and accurate report to the city council of all burial lots sold, graves opened and closed and money received during the preceding month, to which report shall be attached a receipt from the city treasurer evidencing that all money collected by the sexton has been remitted to the city treasurer at the times and in accordance with the rules established by the city manager. 
(Prior code § 10-5) 
13.64.070 - City to care for lots and grounds. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this title, all grading, landscape work and improvements of any kind, and all care of lots, shall be done by the city, and all trees, shrubs and herbage of any kind shall be planted, trimmed, cut or removed, and all opening or closing of graves and all interments, disinterments or removals shall be made by the city. 
(Ord. 884,§ 7, 1987) 
13.64.080 - City not required to grow grass where difficult. 
    The city shall not be required to try to grow grass under evergreen trees or elsewhere in the city cemetery, if excessive shade or other conditions make growth difficult. 
(Prior code § 10-20) 
13.64.090 - Destruction of monuments. 
    No person shall wilfully ride or drive upon any place within the city cemetery, other than the platted driveways, nor wilfully deface, injure or destroy any monument, tomb, grave or gravestone or any board or any other object set to mark any grave, nor break, injure or destroy any gate, fence, grass plot, shrub, tree or ornament of any kind within the cemetery 
(Prior code § 10-21) 
13.64.100 - Visitation hours. 
    Visitors are permitted on the cemetery grounds during the regular hours of five a.m. to nine p.m., or sunrise to sunset, whichever occurs first. 
(Ord. 884 § 9, 1987) 
13.64.110 - City liability. 
    The city shall take reasonable precautions to protect lot owners and lots from loss or damage; however, the city shall not have any responsibility for loss or damage from causes beyond its reasonable control, including but not limited to, damage caused by the elements, acts of God, thieves, vandals, riots or order of any military or civil authority. 
(Ord. 884 § 10, 1987) 
13.64.120 - Use of roads and walks required. 
    Persons within the cemetery shall use only the roads, drives or walks as thoroughfares and no person shall walk on the grass unless it is necessary to do so to reach a particular lot, except that a workman may use such space as is necessary to perform maintenance or other services in connection with a lot. Any person using any portion of the cemetery other than the roads, drives or walks as a thoroughfare, is declared to be a trespasser and shall be subject to prosecution. 
(Ord. 884, § 11, 1987) 
13.64.130 - Persons permitted on cemetery lots. 
    Only the lot owner or his relatives or other authorized individuals shall be permitted on any cemetery lot. Any other person thereon shall be considered to be a trespasser and shall be subject to prosecution. 
(Ord. 884, § 12, 1987) 
13.64.140 - Payment required prior to burial-Procedure. 
    All fees, payments or charges for any cemetery property or service shall be paid to the city at the cemetery business office. All applications for purchase, transfer, assignment or repurchase of cemetery lots, interment and disinterment orders, foundation and monument permits, perpetual care or special permits of any kind shall be made at the cemetery business office. Full payments for purchase of plots, and opening/closing shall be made to the cemetery business office prior to any burial. No burial shall be allowed in a burial space on which the perpetual care fee has not been paid or contracted for as provided herein. The burial permit shall be recorded with the cemetery business office prior to any burial. 
(Ord. 884 § 4, 1987; Ord. No. 1642, § 1, 3-19-2013) 
13.64.150 - Burial outside of cemetery prohibited. 
    No person shall bury a dead human body within the city limits except in a cemetery. 
(Ord. 1166 § 2, 1995) 
13.64.160 - Remedies. 
A.  The violation of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be punished as provided in the general penalty section of this code. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to neglect or refuse to remove a dead human body from property which he/she owns or occupies within twenty-four hours after notice from the city manager or person designated by the manager to give notice. If the body is not removed within twenty-four hours of the notice, it shall be deemed a second offense, with each twenty-four hours thereafter being a subsequent offense. 
C.  Nothing in this chapter is intended to prevent the city from seeking injunctive relief to require the disinterment and removal of any human body buried in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1166 § 3, 1995) 
13.64.170 - Zoning ordinances unaffected. 
    Cemeteries may be located in any zone in which they are a principal permitted or conditional use as provided from time to time in the city's zoning ordinances. 
(Ord. 1166 § 4, 1995) 
13.64.180 - Ashes. 
    This chapter does not apply to the disposal of the ashes of a person who has been cremated. 
(Ord. 1166 § 5, 1995) 
Chapter 13.68 - LOTS 
Sections: 

13.68.010 - Purchase. 
    Any person desiring to purchase a burial lot shall make application to the cemetery superintendent or the city sexton, or designated representative, who shall, upon payment of the price of the lot, issue a receipt for such payment and prepare a deed, which shall be submitted to the city council at its first regular meeting of the succeeding month. Upon approval of such deed by the city council, such deed shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk under the seal of the city. Such deed shall be recorded by the city and the cost of recording shall be charged to the purchaser at the time of purchase. Such deed shall specify that the person to whom it is issued is the owner of the lot described therein, and such deed shall vest in the owner the right in fee simple of such lot for the purposes of interment under the regulations of the city council. No person may purchase more than sixteen spaces without the prior approval of the city manager. 
(Prior code § 10-7; Ord. 884 § 14, 1987) 
13.68.030 - Perpetual care-Exceptions. 
A.  All lots or burial spaces shall be sold with perpetual care with the exception of the county dry section for indigent burials. 
B.  Any lot or portion thereof not now under perpetual care may be placed under perpetual care upon application and payment of the required fee. The amount of such fee shall be the amount that is currently being charged on other burial spaces of similar character or in a similar location. No burial shall be allowed in a burial space on which the perpetual care fee has not been paid or contracted for as provided herein. 
C.  General care will be given lots which were originally sold without perpetual care, in order that the general beauty of the cemetery may be maintained. However, the city assumes no responsibility to maintain these lots in perpetuity. Lots having perpetual care shall in every case have preference for city care. 
(Prior code § 10-9; Ord. 884 § 16, 1987) 
13.68.040 - Perpetual care-Contracts. 
    On all cemetery lots heretofore purchased, the city may enter into a contract with the purchaser for perpetual care thereon. 
(Prior code § 10-10; Ord. 884 § 17, 1987) 
13.68.060 - Perpetual care-Account. 
    The city treasurer shall be the custodian of the city cemetery perpetual care account and shall receive all money collected by the city manager or the city sexton for perpetual care under the provisions of this division. Funds so received shall be kept separate and apart in the general or other funds of the city. The city treasurer shall invest funds so received in any manner provided by state law. All income derived from the investment of such funds shall be paid into the general fund of the city and shall be subject to budget and expenditure by the city, the same as any other funds received into such general fund. 
(Prior code § 10-12) 
13.68.070 - Disposition of funds collected by sexton.
